Kingsford began working as a freelance illustrator for magazines and books, including the Radio Times and the Dorling Kindersley Eyewitness series. His illustrations often accompanied articles and texts about travel, nature, and history. Style and Themes Kingsford's style was characterized by his use of vivid colors and bold brushwork, which gave his works a distinctive, impressionistic quality. He often depicted rural and coastal landscapes, capturing the changing light and atmospheric effects with a keen eye for detail. In addition to his landscapes, Kingsford also painted portraits, still lifes, and scenes from daily life. His work was praised for its emotional depth and sensitivity, as well as its technical mastery. Later Life and Legacy Kingsford continued to paint and exhibit his work well into his later years, with his last exhibition taking place in 2001. He also taught at various art schools, including the Royal College of Art and the Central School of Art and Design. Today, Kingsford is remembered as one of the leading British painters of the 20th century, with his works held in collections around the world. His legacy continues to inspire and influence artists in the United Kingdom and beyond.

Josephine Platner Shear (1890-1971) was an American entrepreneur and inventor best known for creating the first practical and commercially viable hairpin that became a staple hair accessory for women of all ages. Born in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, Shear grew up in a family of inventors and entrepreneurs. Her grandfather was a prominent inventor and entrepreneur who established a successful manufacturing business in Pittsburgh. Her father, a businessman himself, worked closely with his father and was involved in the family’s manufacturing business. Shear attended the University of Pittsburgh, where she studied engineering and developed a keen interest in mechanical design. After graduation, she worked for several years in business management before turning her attention to her true passion: inventing. In 1919, Shear came up with the idea for a new kind of hairpin that was more practical and secure than the bulky, ornamental hairpins popular at the time. She spent several years perfecting her design, experimenting with different materials and shapes, until she developed a pin that was slim, flexible, and easy to use. She patented her invention in 1925 and founded the J.B. Shear Manufacturing Company, naming it after her father. Initially, she marketed her hairpins under the brand name “Bob Pins” but later changed it to “Bobby Pins,” which became the popular term for the thin, U-shaped hair accessory. Despite facing resistance and skepticism from industry insiders who doubted the viability of her product, Shear persevered and built a successful business around her invention. In addition to her success with hairpins, Shear also patented several other inventions, including a cordless electric fishing reel and a silverware cleaning device. Shear passed away in 1971, but her legacy lives on in the ubiquitous bobby pin, which remains a staple hair accessory to this day. She is remembered as a pioneering inventor and entrepreneur who broke barriers and challenged norms in a male-dominated field.

The Association of International Schools in Africa (AISA) is a non-profit organization that was established in 1969. It is a membership organization that represents international schools in Africa and assists them in providing quality education to students from diverse cultures and backgrounds. AISA is committed to promoting the growth and development of international education on the African continent. AISA provides a network of support to its member schools, which includes professional development opportunities, accreditation services, and leadership programs. It also provides a platform for member schools to collaborate and exchange best practices, which ultimately improves the quality of education delivered to students. The association has a diverse network of member schools that caters to the needs of students from different age groups, backgrounds, and cultures. Member schools provide primary, secondary and tertiary education, and are located in a broad range of regions across Africa. AISA is also committed to developing strong relationships with local communities and promoting social responsibility in its member schools. It ensures that its member schools support local initiatives and contribute towards social and economic development in their respective communities. The association is governed by a board of directors who are elected by its members. The board is responsible for strategic planning, policy development, and overseeing the operations of the association. Overall, AISA plays a crucial role in fostering the growth and development of international education in Africa. It provides a platform for international schools to collaborate and exchange ideas, which ultimately improves the quality of education provided to students.

Macbett is a play written by Eugène Ionesco, a prominent figure of the Theatre of the Absurd movement. It was first published in 1972 and later performed at the Théâtre de Paris in 1973. The play is a parody of William Shakespeare's Macbeth, exploring the themes of power, corruption, and the destructive nature of ambition. The play is set in a Scottish court, where Macbett, played by a woman in some productions, is an honest and loyal general to Duncan, the king. However, a group of witches, played by men in some productions, predict that Macbett will overthrow Duncan and take the throne for herself. Driven by ambition and greed, Macbett murders Duncan and becomes the new ruler. She then proceeds to eliminate anyone who stands in her way, including her friend Banco, who is turned against her by a spell. Throughout the play, Ionesco employs his characteristic absurdity and surrealism, with the representation of witches as military generals, anthropomorphic crowns that talk, and soldiers wearing tutus and clown makeup. The play also includes elements of farce and black comedy, providing a satirical commentary on human nature and the desire for power. Macbett has been received with mixed reviews over the years, with some critics praising its wit and subversiveness, while others considered it to be a weak imitation of Shakespeare. Despite this, the play has remained popular and has been performed in numerous countries, including France, Italy, Poland, and the United States. In conclusion, Macbett remains a significant work of the Theatre of the Absurd, exemplifying the movement's rejection of conventional dramatic conventions and the use of absurdity as a means of exploring complex societal issues.

Gunārs Meierovics - Latvian Statesman Gunārs Meierovics was a Latvian statesman who served as the Prime Minister of Latvia and played a significant role in the country's War of Independence. He was born on September 28, 1887, in a small town called Talsi located in the western region of Latvia and died on April 22, 1925. Meierovics studied law at the University of St. Petersburg, Russia. After he completed his education, he returned to Latvia and became an active participant in the country's political scene. In 1915, during World War I, he played a leading role in the Latvian Riflemen's Battalions (Latviešu strēlnieki), which played a crucial role in repelling the German drive towards Petrograd. After Latvia declared independence on November 18, 1918, he was appointed as the Minister of Foreign Affairs in the Provisional Government of Latvia. He served in this role until 1921 and then went on to become the Prime Minister of Latvia from 1921 to 1924. Meierovics was a pragmatic politician who understood the importance of foreign alliances and trade ties for Latvia. Under his leadership, Latvia established friendly relations with several countries, including Great Britain and the United States. He also made significant efforts to strengthen the Latvian economy through trade agreements. Meierovics' leadership was vital during a period of great instability both in Latvia and internationally. His government managed to stabilize Latvia's political situation, allowing it to focus on the rebuilding of the country's infrastructure and security. Meierovics, however, faced many challenges during his tenure as Prime Minister. The country was plagued by economic problems, with high inflation rates and unemployment. Ethnic tensions were also high, with many Russians and Germans living in Latvia. He also faced criticism from opposition parties for his pro-Western policies and his handling of a growing corruption scandal involving members of his government. Meierovics passed away in 1925, and his untimely death was a significant loss for Latvia. Despite only serving as Prime Minister for three years, he remains an important figure in Latvian history, known for his role in Latvia's independence and his efforts to establish strong relationships with other countries. His legacy continues to inspire Latvians to this day and is a symbol of national pride and determination.

Heisenberg's microscope is a thought experiment proposed by the German physicist Werner Heisenberg in 1927 to illustrate the limitations of measuring in quantum mechanics. This concept is based on the uncertainty principle, which says that the position and momentum of an object cannot be known simultaneously with unlimited precision. According to the thought experiment, if we want to measure the position of a subatomic particle accurately, we need to shine light on it. However, the act of shining light changes the momentum of the particle, and as a result, the position becomes less precise. Vice versa, if we want to measure the momentum of the particle accurately, we need to use a microscope with a smaller wavelength, which increases the momentum of the photon and correspondingly decreases the precision in position. The Heisenberg's microscope experiment is based on the assumption that a microscope is capable of examining an object with unlimited precision. However, conventional microscopes function on classical optics principles, which indeed cannot overcome the limitations of the Heisenberg uncertainty principle. The experiment has significant implications for various quantum-mechanical phenomena, including the wave-particle duality and the complementarity principle. It points to the fundamental uncertainty of the foundational principles of physics and shows us that there is a limit to our ability to understand the physical world. Some proposed variations on the thought experiment include using neutron sources instead of light, suggesting the possibility of more precise measurements, but still limited by the uncertainty principle. In summary, Heisenberg's microscope thought experiment has greatly contributed to our understanding of the limits of measurement and the uncertainty principle. It highlights the fundamental principles of quantum mechanics and reminds us that there is much to be uncovered yet about the nature of matter and energy.

Guitar Tango is a style of music that blends the traditional Argentine tango with elements of Western guitar music. It first emerged in the late 1950s and early 1960s and quickly became popular in both Argentina and internationally. The sound of Guitar Tango is characterized by the use of the electric guitar as a lead instrument, often playing long, sweeping melodies that mirror the movements of the tango dance. The guitar is typically accompanied by acoustic instruments such as the bandoneón, a type of accordion traditionally used in Argentine tango music, as well as piano, double bass, and drums. One of the pioneers of Guitar Tango was the Argentine guitarist and composer, Eduardo Falú. His influential album, Guitarra Mía, released in 1959, featured a number of original compositions that incorporated tango rhythms and melodies. Other notable Guitar Tango musicians include Astor Piazzolla, who is widely regarded as one of the most important tango composers of the 20th century, and the Spanish guitarist, Paco de Lucía, who fused elements of flamenco and tango in his compositions. Guitar Tango has been embraced by musicians around the world and has evolved over time to incorporate a wide range of styles and influences. Modern examples of Guitar Tango might feature elements of jazz, rock, or even electronic music, but all share a respect for the rich tradition of Argentine tango. Guitar Tango is a dynamic and exciting style of music that continues to inspire musicians and dancers around the globe. Its fusion of different cultures and musical traditions is a testament to the power of art to bring people together and bridge divides.

Prime Suspect is an American television series that aired on NBC from September 22, 2011, to January 22, 2012. The show is a crime drama that centers around Detective Jane Timoney, played by Maria Bello, and her experiences as a homicide detective in a male-dominated police department. Prime Suspect is based on the British television series of the same name, which aired in the UK from 1991 to 2006. However, the American version of the show differs from the original in several significant ways, including the setting, the characters, and the storylines. In the American version, Jane Timoney is a seasoned detective from Brooklyn who transfers to the NYPD's homicide division in Manhattan. She faces constant scrutiny and skepticism from her male colleagues, who doubt her capabilities as a woman in the male-dominated field. Despite the challenges she faces, Timoney is a determined and skilled detective who is dedicated to solving every case she is assigned. Throughout the series, she takes on a variety of complex cases, including a serial killer who targets young women and a case involving a missing teenage girl. The show received generally positive reviews from critics, who praised Bello's performance as Timoney and the show's depiction of the challenges faced by women in law enforcement. However, despite its critical acclaim, Prime Suspect was canceled after only one season due to low ratings. In addition to Bello, the show also starred Aidan Quinn, Kirk Acevedo, Brian O'Byrne, and Tim Griffin. The show was created by Alexandra Cunningham and was produced by Universal Television and ITV Studios America. Overall, Prime Suspect is a compelling and thought-provoking crime drama that explores the complex relationships between law enforcement officials and the challenges faced by women in the field. While the series was short-lived, its impact on the representation of women in television and entertainment continues to be felt today.

Gjemnessund Bridge is a historic bridge located in the northern part of Norway. It connects the municipalities of Hemne and Snillfjord, crossing the Gjemnessundet strait. The bridge was built in 1936 and has a total length of 539 meters. The Gjemnessund Bridge plays an important role in the transportation system of the region. It is the only bridge that connects the two municipalities, providing a vital link for commuters, tourists and goods transportation. The original bridge was designed as a steel arch bridge with a main span of 123 meters. However, due to the heavy traffic in the region, it was later upgraded to a concrete bridge with a wider deck and a higher load capacity. The construction of the new bridge began in 2005 and was completed in 2008. The new bridge has a total length of 573 meters, with a main span of 140 meters. It has a total of 11 spans and is supported by 9 piers. The bridge deck is 13 meters wide, providing ample space for two lanes of traffic and pedestrians. The Gjemnessund Bridge is not only functional, but also a striking landmark of the region. Its unique design and location make it a popular destination for tourists, photographers and nature lovers. The bridge offers stunning views of the surrounding mountains and fjords, and is particularly spectacular during the winter months when it is covered in snow. Today, the Gjemnessund Bridge stands as a testament to the skills and ingenuity of Norwegian engineers and construction workers. It remains an important part of the transportation network and a symbol of the region's rich history and culture.

The Big 5 is a term commonly used to describe the five largest animals found in Africa. They are the African elephant, the African lion, the African leopard, the African buffalo, and the Black rhinoceros. These animals are often the focus of safaris and wildlife documentaries due to their size, strength, and majesty. African elephants are the largest land animals on earth and can weigh up to 10,000 pounds. They are known for their long trunks and large ears, which they use to communicate with other elephants. African lions are also known as “King of the Jungle” for their majestic appearance and their role as apex predators. They are skilled hunters and live in prides, which are social groups made up of females, cubs, and a dominant male. African leopards are elusive and solitary creatures that are known for their ability to climb trees and drag prey up into them for safekeeping. African buffaloes, also known as Cape buffaloes, are large and aggressive herbivores that can weigh up to 1,500 pounds. They live in herds and are known for their unpredictable and dangerous behavior. Finally, Black rhinoceros are one of the most endangered animals in the world, and are known for their large size and thick, armored skin. They are often poached for their horns, which are falsely believed to have medicinal properties. The Big 5 are a vital part of Africa’s ecosystem and play an important role in maintaining the balance of the region’s wildlife. However, all of these animals face threats from habitat loss, poaching, and other human activities. Conservation efforts are underway to protect these species and ensure that future generations can appreciate their beauty and importance. Various African countries have established national parks and wildlife reserves where tourists can view the Big 5 in their natural habitats.

Fred Perrett was a well-known Australian artist and academic, born on 12th November 1925 in Sydney, Australia. He was best known for his vibrant portraits, landscapes and unique abstract compositions. Early Life and Education: Fred Perrett grew up in the eastern suburbs of Sydney, where he developed an early interest in art. He enrolled in the East Sydney Technical College (now National Art School) where he studied under renowned artists such as William Dobell and Frank Hinder. Career: Perrett began his career as a freelance artist working in various media such as oil, acrylic, and watercolor. He gained recognition for his unique technique where he used a palette knife to apply paint on the canvas, giving his paintings a distinctive quality. Perrett was also a skilled teacher and academic. He taught art and design at various institutions including the National Art School, Alexander Mackie College, and the University of New South Wales. He was a mentor to several students who went on to become successful artists themselves. Perrett's paintings were exhibited in several group and solo exhibitions throughout Australia. His artworks were also featured in many private and public collections including the Art Gallery of New South Wales, the National Gallery of Victoria and the Canberra Museum and Gallery. Personal Life and Legacy: Perrett was married to Australian artist, Margaret Loxton. The couple had two children. Perrett died on 9th October 2009, leaving behind a legacy of unique, vibrant and dynamic artworks. Fred Perrett's contribution to the Australian art scene has been celebrated through various retrospectives and exhibitions. His distinctive style and technique continue to inspire and influence contemporary Australian artists.

Uppåkra is an archaeological site located in southern Sweden, near the town of Lund. It was a significant center of power and trade during the Iron Age and Viking Age, dating from approximately 200-1050 AD. Uppåkra was one of the most important places in Scandinavia during this time, and it is considered one of the country's most important archaeological sites. The site was first discovered in the 1930s and has been extensively excavated since then. Some of the most significant findings include the remains of an early Christian church, a large marketplace, and a number of residential buildings, as well as the remains of a defensive wall and several fortresses. Uppåkra was a major trading center, connecting the Baltic region with continental Europe and the British Isles. The site was strategically located at the intersection of several important trade routes, and it is believed to have played a key role in the development of the Viking Age trade networks. The area around Uppåkra is rich in resources such as iron, timber, and fertile land, making it an attractive location for settlement. The site is also notable for its early Christian church, one of the oldest in Sweden, which was built in the 900s. The church was likely built to serve the growing Christian population in the area, and it has been suggested that the construction of the church was encouraged by the local ruling elite as a way to help legitimize their power. Today, visitors can see the remains of Uppåkra's fortifications, marketplaces, and residential buildings. The site is open to the public and has a small museum showcasing some of the most significant finds from the excavations. Uppåkra remains an important site for researchers studying the history and archaeology of the Iron Age and Viking Age in Scandinavia, as well as for individuals interested in the region's cultural heritage.

NDUFAF5 is a protein that is encoded by the NDUFAF5 gene. This gene is located on chromosome 9 and is believed to play a crucial role in the function of the complex I of the mitochondrial respiratory chain. Mitochondria are organelles that are responsible for the production of ATP, the energy currency of the cell. The respiratory chain is a series of protein complexes that are involved in energy production. NDUFAF5 is a subunit of complex I, which is the first complex in the respiratory chain. NDUFAF5 has been shown to be essential for the stability and activity of complex I. Studies have suggested that mutations in the NDUFAF5 gene can lead to complex I dysfunction and mitochondrial disorders. One specific disorder that has been linked to mutations in NDUFAF5 is Leigh syndrome, a progressive neurological disorder that is characterized by the degeneration of the central nervous system. NDUFAF5 is a highly conserved protein, meaning that it is similar across different species. This suggests that it plays an important role in the function of complex I in all organisms. Additionally, the expression of NDUFAF5 has been found to be regulated by several factors, including reactive oxygen species and hypoxia. Research into the function of NDUFAF5 is ongoing, and its potential as a therapeutic target for mitochondrial disorders is being explored. Understanding the role of NDUFAF5 in complex I function could lead to the development of new treatments for complex I dysfunction and mitochondrial disorders. In conclusion, NDUFAF5 is a crucial protein that plays a key role in the function of complex I in the mitochondrial respiratory chain. Mutations in the NDUFAF5 gene have been linked to mitochondrial disorders, including Leigh syndrome. Further research into the function of NDUFAF5 could lead to the development of new treatments for these disorders.

"The Great White Way" is a 1924 drama film that is considered a silent classic. Directed by E. Mason Hopper, the film tells the story of Rose Donovan, a young woman who dreams of becoming a Broadway star. The film is also known for featuring one of Hollywood's most iconic actresses, Anita Stewart. Shot in New York City, the film captures the excitement and glamour of Broadway during the 1920s. The film's title refers to the nickname given to the theater district on Broadway that was illuminated by electric lights at night. The Great White Way was one of the popular tourist attractions in New York City at the time. The film follows Rose Donovan, played by Anita Stewart, who is a chorus girl in a Broadway show. She has dreams of becoming a star, but her ambition is met with challenges, including the advances of her married producer, played by Creighton Hale. She also finds herself in a love triangle with two men, one of whom is a successful producer and the other a struggling playwright. The film's plot is a timeless tale of ambition and love, still relevant today, almost a century later. The film showcased the beauty and grandeur of Broadway, and the excellent performances of the cast made the movie a tremendous success. Fans of Anita Stewart and silent-era films still seek out this classic Hollywood film to this day. "The Great White Way" leaves a lasting impact on the film industry in Hollywood, as it remains a shining example of the glamour that Broadway presented, and the challenges that must be met to achieve one's dreams. The film is a must-see for those interested in early Hollywood and the decadence of New York's theatre district.

Vulcano is a small island located in the Aeolian archipelago, north of Sicily in Italy. It is famous for its active volcano, which has been erupting since 183 BCE. The island is also known for its therapeutic mud baths and beautiful beaches. Geologically, Vulcano is part of a chain of volcanoes that extends from Mount Etna in Sicily to Stromboli in the north. The island has several volcanic vents, including Fossa crater, which is the highest point on the island at 391 meters. The volcanic activity on Vulcano has created a unique landscape, with black sand beaches and sulfuric hot springs. The island has been a popular destination for tourists since ancient times, with the Romans visiting the island for its thermal baths. The island is also known for its use in the literary world, featuring as the location of the final scene in Jules Verne's "Journey to the Center of the Earth". Today, visitors to Vulcano can take guided tours of the volcano and its crater, as well as enjoy the island's natural mud baths. The mud baths are said to have therapeutic properties, with visitors covering themselves in the mud and allowing it to dry before rinsing it off in the sea. While the island is famous for its natural beauty, Vulcano is also home to a small community of residents who work in tourism and fishing. The island is accessible by ferry from the nearby town of Milazzo in Sicily, making it a popular day trip destination. Overall, Vulcano is a unique and beautiful island, rich in history and geological wonders. Its active volcano and mud baths make it a must-visit destination for those exploring the Aeolian islands.

George Kent Performance Hall is a world-class performing arts center located in the heart of downtown Spokane, Washington. The hall is named after George Kent, a renowned philanthropist and arts patron, who envisioned a space that would inspire and entertain audiences from around the world. The George Kent Performance Hall is a state-of-the-art venue that has been designed to host a diverse range of performing arts, including ballet, opera, musical theater, and concerts. The auditorium itself is a beautiful space, with a seating capacity of 2,700 people and excellent acoustics. It is a popular venue for local and international performers and has hosted many world-renowned artists, including the Vienna Symphony Orchestra, Yo-Yo Ma, and the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater. The hall is also a hub for community events and activities, providing a platform for local artists and performers to showcase their talent. It is a regular venue for local dance schools, music festivals, and theater productions, and has helped generate a strong cultural identity for Spokane. The George Kent Performance Hall is more than just a venue, it is a place where people come together to celebrate the arts and to be moved by the power of performance. The hall is managed by a team of dedicated professionals who are committed to providing exceptional service to ensure that every event is a success. In recognition of his contributions to the arts community, George Kent was awarded several prestigious honors, including the Governor's Arts Award and the Spokane Citizen Hall of Fame. His legacy lives on through the George Kent Performance Hall, which continues to inspire and delight audiences of all ages.

Megalopalpus zymna is a species of beetle belonging to the family Scarabaeidae. Commonly known as the "Brazilian scarab beetle," this species is found in the Amazon rainforests of Brazil, Colombia, Ecuador, and Peru. Megalopalpus zymna is known for its vibrant, metallic-green coloration, which makes it highly sought after by collectors and enthusiasts. Adult M. zymna beetles are relatively large, with bodies measuring up to 3 centimeters in length. Both males and females have an elongated, oval-shaped body and long, slender legs. The most distinctive feature of M. zymna is its metallic-green exoskeleton, which is punctuated by small, irregularly shaped depressions and ridges. This coloration is caused by the reflection and refraction of light on the beetle's exoskeleton, a phenomenon known as iridescence. M. zymna beetles spend much of their lives underground, feeding on the roots of trees and other vegetation. After a gestation period lasting several months, adult beetles will emerge from the soil in search of a mate. Females lay their eggs in the soil, and the resulting larvae will spend several years developing before emerging as adults. Despite their relative obscurity, M. zymna beetles have become a popular species among collectors and hobbyists in recent years. The loss of their native habitat due to deforestation, however, has led to concerns about the long-term sustainability of the species. Some efforts are currently underway to protect the Amazon rainforests and preserve the habitats of M. zymna and other endangered species.

James Hodge Codding (October 8, 1878 – November 20, 1964) was an American real estate developer who played a significant role in the development of Downtown Oklahoma City in the early and mid-20th century. He is considered one of the most prominent developers in Oklahoma City's history. Born in Emporia, Kansas, Codding moved to Oklahoma City in 1903. He began his career working for a lumber company and, later, opened his own wooden box manufacturing plant. However, it was his development of real estate that would make him a name in Oklahoma City. Codding started his career by building two-story brick buildings in Oklahoma City, which eventually led to the construction of larger structures, including the 12-story Guaranty Bank Building, which was Oklahoma City's first skyscraper and the first building to employ a caisson foundation system. Codding founded the Oklahoma City Chamber of Commerce's Industrial Development division, which helped bring new industries to the area and played a significant role in the city's growth. During World War II, Codding's firm built a housing development for military families in Midwest City, which at the time was a suburb of Oklahoma City. Later, in the 1950s, Codding had a vision of transforming downtown Oklahoma City into a modern metropolis. He collaborated with other businessmen and city officials to build a network of elevated walkways that would connect buildings and create a pedestrian-friendly atmosphere. The walkways, known as “Skywalks,” are still in existence today. Codding died in 1964 at the age of 86. Today, his legacy can be seen throughout Oklahoma City, where many of the buildings he constructed are still standing and continue to be an important part of the city's landscape.

Persecution of Biharis in Bangladesh refers to the systematic targeting of Bihari Muslims who migrated to East Pakistan (now Bangladesh) during the partition of India in 1947. Since then, the Bihari community has faced discrimination and violence, particularly during the 1971 Bangladesh Liberation War when the community was seen as supporting Pakistan. The Bihari community had migrated to East Pakistan during the partition of India, hoping to find a new home in what would be the state of Pakistan. However, they were seen as supporters of Pakistan during the 1971 war, leading to widespread violence and discrimination against them. Many Biharis were killed, raped, and tortured, and thousands were forced to flee to refugee camps in Pakistan. Despite the end of the war and the creation of Bangladesh, the Bihari community continued to face persecution and marginalization. They have been denied citizenship, legal recognition, and the right to education and employment. Many continue to live in squalid refugee camps with inadequate access to basic necessities like healthcare and food. In recent years, there have been some efforts to address the plight of the Bihari community. The government of Bangladesh has granted citizenship to some Biharis, and international organizations have advocated for their rights. However, many Biharis continue to live in desperate conditions and face ongoing discrimination and violence. The persecution of Biharis in Bangladesh is a tragic example of the impact of political and ethnic conflict on vulnerable communities. It underscores the importance of protecting the rights of marginalized groups and promoting tolerance and understanding among diverse communities.

The Sound of Missing You is a heart-touching song written by Australian singer-songwriter Ameerah. The song conveys the pain and longing of being apart from a loved one and the emptiness that comes with missing them. Released in 2012, the song has become an anthem for those dealing with the feeling of separation. The somber melody and haunting vocals perfectly capture the emotions of missing someone deeply. The Sound of Missing You has gained enormous popularity since its release, with the music video amassing over 23 million views on YouTube. The song has been praised for its emotional depth and powerful lyrics. The lyrics of the song convey the pain of being apart and the yearning to be reunited with a loved one. The chorus of the song goes: "The sound of missing you Is like a symphony A melody that haunts me And it echoes through the night" Ameerah's beautiful vocals and the gentle piano accompaniment work together to create a deeply moving experience that resonates with listeners. In addition to its popularity as a standalone song, The Sound of Missing You has been featured in numerous TV shows and films. The song has also been covered by several artists, each interpreting it in their unique ways. The Sound of Missing You is an emotional masterpiece, showcasing Ameerah's exceptional songwriting skills. It is a song that people turn to when they're feeling lonely and in need of comfort. It speaks to the universal human experience of loss and the longing for connection.

Malate dehydrogenase (NADP+) is an enzyme that is found in living organisms, including plants, animals, and microorganisms. This enzyme plays a vital role in the citric acid cycle, also known as the Krebs cycle, which is a series of chemical reactions that occur in the mitochondria. The citric acid cycle is responsible for the breakdown of carbohydrates and fats and produces energy in the form of ATP. Malate dehydrogenase (NADP+) catalyzes the conversion of malate to oxaloacetate in the presence of NADP+. The enzyme does this by transferring electrons from malate to NADP+, which results in the formation of NADPH. NADPH is a coenzyme that serves as an electron donor in various metabolic processes. The conversion of malate to oxaloacetate is an essential step in the citric acid cycle, as oxaloacetate is required for the next step in the cycle. Malate dehydrogenase (NADP+) is an important enzyme in cellular metabolism, as it helps to regulate the levels of NADPH and malate in the cell. NADPH is required for a variety of cellular processes, including nucleic acid synthesis, fatty acid synthesis and cholesterol biosynthesis. Malate, on the other hand, is an intermediate in the citric acid cycle and can be used by the cell to produce energy. The structure of malate dehydrogenase (NADP+) is complex. It is a homodimeric enzyme, meaning that it is made up of two identical subunits. Each subunit has a molecular weight of approximately 35 kDa. The enzyme contains a binding site for NADP+ and a catalytic site for malate. In conclusion, Malate dehydrogenase (NADP+) is a crucial enzyme in the citric acid cycle, which is responsible for energy production in living organisms. The enzyme catalyzes the conversion of malate to oxaloacetate in the presence of NADP+, producing NADPH. Malate dehydrogenase (NADP+) is an essential enzyme for various metabolic processes, including nucleic acid synthesis, fatty acid synthesis, and cholesterol biosynthesis. Its structure is complex and consists of two identical subunits, each containing a binding site for NADP+ and a catalytic site for malate.

Thrice Woven is the fifth studio album released by the American black metal band Wolves in the Throne Room. The album was released on September 22, 2017, through the band's own label, Artemisia Records. The album explores themes related to nature, mysticism, and transcendence. The album consists of five tracks, all of which showcase the band's signature blend of atmospheric black metal and ambient music. The album opens with "Born from the Serpent's Eye," a nine-minute track that sets the tone for the rest of the album with its slow-building atmosphere and vivid imagery. "The Old Ones Are with Us" and "Angrboda" are both mid-tempo tracks that feature haunting melodies and intricate guitar work. The album's centerpiece is the nearly 12-minute-long "Mother Owl, Father Ocean," which begins with an eerie soundscape and builds to a powerful crescendo of distorted guitars and thunderous drums. The album concludes with "Fires Roar in the Palace of the Moon," a somber and reflective track that brings the album to a satisfying close. Thrice Woven was well-received by critics, many of whom praised the album's epic scope and emotional depth. The album charted on a number of Billboard's charts, including the Heatseekers Chart and the Independent Albums chart. Overall, Thrice Woven is a masterful work of atmospheric black metal that cements Wolves in the Throne Room's place as one of the most important bands in the genre. The album is a must-listen for fans of black metal and atmospheric music alike.

Shim Soon-taek is a South Korean social activist and the wife of former United Nations Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon. She is known for her efforts towards the promotion of women's rights, particularly in conflict zones around the world. Born in 1944 in South Korea, Shim Soon-taek grew up in a family that emphasized education. She earned a degree in French literature from Ewha Womans University in Seoul. After completing her studies, she began working with women's organizations, where her passion for social justice began to take root. Throughout her career, Shim Soon-taek has been a vocal advocate for the empowerment of women and girls. She has traveled to conflict zones worldwide, including in Africa and the Middle East, to promote the importance of education for women. In 2008, she was named a UN Women's Watch Vigilante, recognizing her efforts to champion women's rights. Shim Soon-taek has been an influential force in expanding international support for victims of sexual violence in conflict. In 2013, she launched the Fund to End Violence Against Women, which aims to provide sustainable financial resources to support local organizations working to address issues of gender-based violence. Beyond her work on women's rights, Shim Soon-taek has also been involved in a variety of philanthropic efforts. She has worked with organizations including the Ban Ki-moon Foundation for a Better Future and the World Health Organization, and has been recognized for her efforts with numerous awards, including the Global Citizenship Award from the Harvard Kennedy School in 2010. Shim Soon-taek remains an outspoken advocate for women and girls, and continues to dedicate her life to promoting equality and justice around the world.

"I'm Moving On" is a song by Yoko Ono, released in 1974 on her album "A Story". The song has since been covered by several artists, including Chaka Khan and John Lennon. The song features Ono's signature avant-garde style, with sparse instrumentation and haunting vocals. The lyrics speak of letting go and moving on from a past relationship, with lines like "I'm moving on, leaving behind what's gone." Despite being released during a time when Ono's solo work was often overshadowed by her relationship with Lennon, "I'm Moving On" has since become a fan favorite and a testament to Ono's artistry. The song's message of resilience and personal growth has resonated with listeners over the years, and many have interpreted it as Ono's statement on her own journey in the wake of Lennon's tragic death in 1980. In 1995, "I'm Moving On" was covered by legendary R&B singer Chaka Khan for her album "Dare You to Love Me". The cover featured more upbeat instrumentation and Khan's powerhouse vocals, but still maintained the song's emotional intensity. John Lennon also covered the song during his and Ono's "Lost Weekend" period, although the recording was not officially released until years later. Overall, "I'm Moving On" remains a powerful and poignant song, highlighting Yoko Ono's importance as both an avant-garde artist and a trailblazer for female musicians in the male-dominated rock industry.

Ferdinand Johann Adam von Pernau was an important figure in the history of the Austrian Empire during the late 18th and early 19th centuries. He was born in Vienna, Austria, in 1755, and received a good education in music, languages, and the liberal arts at the Theresianum, an elite school in the city. After completing his studies, Pernau entered the diplomatic service, where he served as a secretary and interpreter for the Austrian ambassador to France. In 1792, he was appointed ambassador to the Ottoman Empire, where he worked to improve relations between the two nations. During his tenure as ambassador, Pernau was involved in several important diplomatic missions. In 1798, he was sent to Egypt to negotiate a peace treaty with Napoleon Bonaparte, who had recently invaded the country. Pernau's efforts were unsuccessful, and he was eventually recalled to Vienna. Despite his setbacks, Pernau remained an important figure in Austrian politics and diplomacy. In 1804, he was appointed to the Privy Council, a high-ranking advisory body to the emperor. He later became a member of the Senate, the upper house of the Austrian parliament. Pernau was also a noted author and scholar. He wrote several works on the history of music, as well as a three-volume memoir of his experiences in the diplomatic service. He was also a skilled linguist, fluent in French, Italian, Turkish, and other languages. Ferdinand Johann Adam von Pernau died in Vienna in 1832 at the age of 77. His contributions to Austrian diplomacy and scholarship continue to be recognized and celebrated today.

Italian Trade Agency The Italian Trade Agency (ITA) is the government agency responsible for promoting the internationalization of Italian companies and the attraction of foreign investment to Italy. It operates in over 80 countries around the world, with a network of offices and representatives offering a wide range of services to companies and investors. History The Italian Trade Agency was established in 2010 from the merger of the Italian Institute for Foreign Trade (ICE) and the Italian Foreign Trade Commission (CST). ICE was founded in 1935 to promote Italian exports abroad, while CST was established in 1919 to encourage foreign investment in Italy. Functions The Italian Trade Agency provides comprehensive support to Italian companies looking to expand their business in international markets, with a focus on promoting the excellence of Made in Italy products. Its services include market research, matchmaking with international partners, participation in international trade fairs and events, and support for certification and intellectual property protection. In addition, the ITA also works to attract foreign investment to Italy, with a dedicated division offering support to foreign companies interested in establishing a presence in the country. This includes assistance with the establishment of legal and fiscal structures, identification of suitable locations and partners, and support for recruitment and training. Organization The Italian Trade Agency is headed by a President and is overseen by a Board of Directors appointed by the Italian Ministry of Economic Development. It operates a central office in Rome, along with regional offices in Italy and a network of foreign offices and representatives in over 80 countries. Conclusion The Italian Trade Agency plays a vital role in promoting the internationalization of Italian companies and attracting foreign investment to the country, serving as a bridge between Italian businesses and global markets. Its services and support have helped many Italian companies succeed in international markets and have also contributed to the growth and development of the Italian economy.

Kim Jong-suk was a prominent Korean independence fighter and politician born in April 1917 in Hoeryong, now part of North Korea. She was the first wife of the founding leader of North Korea, Kim Il-sung, and the mother of former North Korean leader, Kim Jong-il. Kim Jong-suk is affectionately known as the "Mother of Korea," and her contributions to the country's liberation and post-war reconstruction remain highly regarded. From an early age, Kim Jong-suk was politically active, participating in the Korean independence movement against Japan. She joined the Korean People's Revolutionary Army in 1932 and rose through the ranks to become a commander. During the Second Sino-Japanese War, she worked with the Chinese Communist Party and fought alongside Chinese revolutionaries, including Mao Zedong. After the end of World War II, Kim Jong-suk played an instrumental role in the establishment of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (DPRK), the official name for North Korea. She served as the first President of the Korean Democratic Women's Union, helping to increase women's participation in politics and advocating for their rights. She also worked closely with her husband, Kim Il-sung, who became the country's first premier. Kim Jong-suk is also remembered for her humanitarian and social efforts. She established orphanages and other social welfare programs across North Korea, and her birthday is celebrated as Mother's Day in North Korea. On September 22, 1949, Kim Jong-suk died from complications following the birth of her third child, Kim Jong-il. She was posthumously honored with the Order of Kim Jong-suk, a high military award in North Korea. Her legacy as a revolutionary and feminist icon remains important in North Korean society, where she is widely revered as a national heroine.

Hedy West (April 6, 1938 – July 3, 2005) was an American folk singer and songwriter known for her contributions to the folk music revival of the 1960s. Born in Cartersville, Georgia, West grew up in a family of Appalachian musicians and learned to play the guitar and the banjo at a young age. West moved to New York City in the early 1960s, where she became involved in the Greenwich Village folk scene. She quickly established herself as a talented singer and songwriter and began performing at popular venues such as Gerde's Folk City and The Gaslight Cafe. West's music was inspired by her Southern roots and often drew upon traditional Appalachian folk songs and ballads. West's song "500 Miles" became a hit for Peter, Paul and Mary in 1962 and was later covered by numerous other artists. She was also known for her songs "Cotton Mill Girls" and "The Ballad of Springhill," which commemorated a mining disaster in Nova Scotia. In addition to her solo career, West also collaborated with other musicians, including Mike Seeger and the New Lost City Ramblers. West continued to perform and record music throughout the 1960s and 1970s, but gradually became less active in the music industry in the following decades. West was recognized for her contributions to folk music with a National Heritage Fellowship from the National Endowment for the Arts in 1990. She continued to be revered among folk music enthusiasts until her death in 2005.

Windhorse is a 1998 film directed by Paul Wagner and written by Julia Elliot. The film explores the struggles and complexities of life in Tibet under Chinese oppression through the eyes of a young, Westernized Tibetan woman named Kelsang. The film received critical acclaim for its sensitive portrayal of the Tibetan people and the challenges they face. The story of Windhorse revolves around Kelsang, a singer who lives in Lhasa and dreams of becoming a successful pop star. She faces numerous obstacles in her quest, including strict government control over the music industry and cultural suppression by the Chinese government. Kelsang's brother Dhondup, who is a Buddhist monk, is involved with the Tibetan resistance movement and has been living underground for many years. When Dhondup is finally caught by the Chinese authorities, Kelsang and her two friends, Pema and Dorje, must choose between their loyalty to him and their desire to avoid getting involved in the struggle. The film is notable for its depiction of Tibetan life under Chinese rule, which has been a contentious issue throughout the world. Wangdu, a Chinese man working for the state-controlled music industry, is portrayed sympathetically, highlighting the complexities of the situation. The film also features stunning cinematography, showcasing the beautiful landscape of Tibet and the vibrant culture of its people. Windhorse was produced by Peter Coyote, who also appears in the film, and was shot on location in Tibet. The film premiered at the Sundance Film Festival in 1998, where it won the Audience Award for Best Dramatic Feature. It went on to receive critical acclaim at festivals around the world, including the Toronto International Film Festival and the Venice Film Festival. Overall, Windhorse is a moving and thought-provoking film that explores issues of culture, politics, and identity in Tibet. Its sensitive portrayal of the Tibetan people and their struggles has made it a beloved classic of independent cinema.

The London Philharmonic Choir is one of the leading choirs in the United Kingdom, known for their performances of classical choral music. The choir was founded in 1946 and has since then become an integral part of the British music scene. The choir has performed with a number of orchestras, including the London Philharmonic Orchestra, with whom they have a long-standing association. They have also collaborated with other leading orchestras such as the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra and the BBC Symphony Orchestra. The London Philharmonic Choir has performed in some of the most prestigious venues in the world, including the Royal Albert Hall, the Barbican Centre, and the Southbank Centre. They have worked with some of the world's leading conductors, such as Sir Adrian Boult, Bernard Haitink, and Klaus Tennstedt. The choir's repertoire covers a wide range of choral music, from the Baroque era to the present day. They have performed works by composers such as Bach, Handel, Mozart, Beethoven, Verdi, and Britten. In addition to their performances, the London Philharmonic Choir is also committed to supporting music education and community outreach. They regularly hold workshops and choral training sessions for young aspiring singers. The choir has released numerous recordings over the years, including a critically acclaimed recording of Britten's War Requiem. They have also been featured in several operatic productions, including productions of Mozart's Don Giovanni and Verdi's Macbeth. The London Philharmonic Choir is led by their current Musical Director, Neville Creed. Under his leadership, the choir continues to be a leading force in the UK classical music scene and a testament to the power and beauty of choral music.

The 53rd Army was a military unit within the Soviet Union. It was formed during World War II, in May 1942, in the Stalingrad region, as an artillery formation. Later on, it was converted into a regular army, becoming part of the Southern Front, which was tasked with defending the Caucasus region. The 53rd Army demonstrated its combat effectiveness during the Battle of Stalingrad, where it played a crucial role in repelling the German forces. After the battle was won, the 53rd Army participated in the liberation of Ukraine and Moldova. It was also involved in the Crimean and Kuban operations, which aimed to destroy the German Army Group South. In June 1944, the 53rd Army was assigned to the 2nd Ukrainian Front. It took part in the battles for the liberation of Romania, Hungary, and Austria. During these battles, the 53rd Army cooperated with other Soviet military units, such as the 46th and 4th Armies. The army's units were composed primarily of infantry, but also included armored and air-defense units. The 53rd Army contributed significantly to the Soviet Union's victory over Nazi Germany. After the war ended, the army was demobilized and its units were disbanded. However, its veterans continued to commemorate their victories and contributions to the Soviet Union's war effort. In conclusion, the 53rd Army was an essential military formation within the Soviet Union during World War II. Its combat effectiveness was proven during crucial battles and campaigns, and its soldiers fought bravely to secure the Soviet Union's victory over Nazi Germany. Today, the memory of the 53rd Army's combat achievements continues to be celebrated and honored.

The 1967–68 Lancashire Cup was the fifth edition of the Rugby League Cup tournament featuring clubs from the Lancashire County Rugby Football League. The tournament began on October 4, 1967, and concluded on February 20, 1968, with Wigan winning the cup after defeating Leigh 6-3 in the final. The Lancashire Cup was one of two county cups run by the Rugby Football League in the north of England, with the other being its counterpart, the Yorkshire Cup. The format of the tournament was a knockout competition with rounds taking place on a home and away basis. The draw for each round was conducted by the Lancashire County Rugby Football League. In the first round of the tournament, favorites Wigan defeated Warrington 19-3 in front of over 7,000 fans at Central Park. Other notable results included Salford defeating Oldham 25-2 and St. Helens defeating Leigh 12-5. The quarter-finals saw St. Helens defeat Widnes 17-7 and Wigan continues their winning ways by defeating Swinton 14-5. In the semi-finals, Wigan defeated Warrington 10-7 in a closely contested match, while Leigh defeated St. Helens by the same scoreline to progress to the final at Station Road Ground in Swinton. The final was a tense and close affair, with Wigan eventually coming out on top 6-3 thanks to a try from Neil Holding and a conversion from Bobbie Goulding. This victory marked Wigan's third Lancashire Cup victory in succession and their fourth overall. The club went on to win a further seven Lancashire Cup titles, bringing their total to eleven. The Lancashire Cup was eventually scrapped in 1993, following the advent of the Rugby League World Cup and changes to the structure of the league system.

1990–91 Division 1 (Senegal) - A Look Back at the Season The 1990–91 Division 1 (Senegal) season was the 28th edition of the top-flight football league in Senegal. The season started in October 1990 and ended in June 1991. It was contested by 16 teams, including the reigning champions, AS Douanes. The league's defending champions started the season on a slow note, picking up just one win in their first five matches. This opened up an opportunity for their title rivals to catch up, and that's exactly what ASC Diaraf and Stade de Mbour did. Diaraf won six of their first eight matches, while Mbour won five of their first seven matches. In the second half of the season, AS Douanes picked up their form, winning four of their last five matches. They finished the season with 32 points, just one point ahead of ASC Diaraf and two points ahead of Stade de Mbour. The top scorer of the season was Babacar Niang of Diaraf, who scored a total of 14 goals in 25 matches. AS Douanes' triumph was a remarkable one as they were able to win the league title after finishing second in the previous season. The club had previously won the Senegalese Premier League four times before the 1990–91 season. Other noteworthy performances during the season included US Gorée's impressive home record, where they scored 24 goals while conceding just three in nine matches. ASC Port Autonome, on the other hand, had a poor season, finishing in 15th place and getting relegated to Division 2. In conclusion, the 1990–91 Division 1 (Senegal) season was a closely contested one that saw AS Douanes emerge as champions. The league showcased some impressive performances from several teams and players, making it a memorable season for the fans.

Ernesto Acher (born July 15, 1956) is an Argentinian musician, composer, and guitar player. He is known for his innovative approach to tango, as well as his extensive work in rock, jazz, and world music. Acher was born in Buenos Aires, Argentina, and began playing the guitar at the age of six. At 16, he formed his first band, Sumo, which became a pioneering force in the Argentinean rock movement. He later went on to study music at the National Music Conservatory in Buenos Aires. In the 1980s, Acher joined the legendary Argentinean tango group Sexteto Nuevo Tango, led by Astor Piazzolla, where he played guitar and contributed to some of the group's most well-known compositions. Acher's own compositions often incorporate elements of tango, rock, and world music. He has released multiple albums, including "4 Lunas", "Taurus Dreams", and "Nuevo Paisaje", all of which showcase his unique style. Throughout his career, Acher has collaborated with many notable musicians, including Danilo Perez, Chano Dominguez, and John McLaughlin. In addition to his musical career, Acher is also a professor at the National Music Conservatory in Buenos Aires, where he teaches guitar and improvisation. He has been recognized for his contributions to music with several awards, including the Konex Award in 1995 and 2005. Acher's influence on Argentinean music and his innovative approach to tango have made him a revered figure in the music world. His work continues to inspire and influence musicians around the globe.

Castillo de San José is a historic fortress located in Arrecife, Lanzarote, Spain. The castle was built in the 18th century by King Charles III of Spain to defend the island against pirate attacks and was completed in 1779. The castle served its military purpose for only a short time before being converted to a prison in the 19th century. In the mid-20th century, the castle was abandoned and left in ruins. However, in 1974, artist and architect César Manrique transformed the site into an art museum dedicated to the works of contemporary artists. Today, the Castillo de San José Contemporary Art Museum is a popular attraction among locals and tourists. The museum has an impressive collection of contemporary art by Spanish and international artists and also hosts temporary exhibitions. The building itself is an impressive sight. The fortress is built of solid blocks of lava stone and is surrounded by a moat. The walls of the castle are thick, and the internal courtyard features a well-preserved drawbridge. Visitors can explore the various rooms of the castle, including the old prison cells, the chapel, and the gunpowder room, which is now the museum's auditorium. In addition to its art collection and historical significance, the Castillo de San José boasts a spectacular location. The fortress is perched on a cliff overlooking the Atlantic Ocean, providing visitors with breathtaking views of the sea and the surrounding landscape. Overall, the Castillo de San José is a remarkable testament to the island's history and evolution and a must-see destination for anyone visiting Lanzarote.

Nemoto Station is a railway station located in the city of Kawasaki, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan. The station is operated by the East Japan Railway Company (JR East) and is on the Nambu Line between Musashi-Kosugi Station and Shitte Station. The station opened on April 1, 1934, and has since served as an important transportation hub for the surrounding community. The station is located near the Nemoto Riverside Park and the Tama River, making it a popular destination for outdoor activities such as cycling, fishing, and kayaking. It is also within walking distance of several local restaurants and shops, making it a convenient place for locals and tourists alike to gather. Nemoto Station has a single island platform serving two tracks, with an elevated station building above the tracks. The station building features a ticket gate, ticket vending machines, and a convenience store. The station is wheelchair accessible, with elevators and ramps available for those who need them. In addition to regular train services, Nemoto Station also serves as a transfer point for several local bus routes. This makes it possible to easily travel to other parts of the city without having to rely on a car or taxi. Overall, Nemoto Station is an important transportation hub for the Kawasaki area and a popular destination for outdoor enthusiasts and those looking to explore the local community. With its convenient location and range of services, it is sure to continue serving the needs of travelers and locals for years to come.

David Hess (born July 10, 1993) is an American professional baseball pitcher who is currently a free agent. He played in Major League Baseball (MLB) for the Baltimore Orioles and Tampa Bay Rays. Hess was born in Tullahoma, Tennessee and attended Tullahoma High School where he played baseball. He went on to play college baseball at Tennessee Technological University, where he became the ace of the pitching staff. Hess was drafted by the Orioles in the fifth round of the 2014 MLB draft. Hess made his MLB debut for the Orioles on May 12, 2018, against the Tampa Bay Rays. He pitched six innings, allowing three runs on four hits and striking out three in a no-decision. Hess recorded his first career win on May 25, 2018, against the Chicago White Sox. He finished his rookie season with a 3-10 record and a 4.88 ERA in 103 innings pitched. Hess was designated for assignment by the Orioles in July 2019 and claimed off waivers by the Rays. He made two appearances for the Rays before being sent down to the minors. He spent the remainder of the 2019 season in the minors and was released by the Rays at the end of the season. In 2020, Hess signed a minor league deal with the New York Yankees and was invited to spring training. However, he was not included on the team's 60-man player pool and did not play in 2020 due to the cancellation of the minor league season. Overall, Hess has a career record of 4-16 with a 5.64 ERA in 192 innings pitched in the major leagues. As a free agent, he is still awaiting his next opportunity in professional baseball.

Terisa Griffin is an American singer, songwriter, and actress with over three decades of experience in the music industry. Born on April 12, 1969 in Monroe, Louisiana, Terisa grew up in Chicago where she honed her skills as a performer. She started out singing in church and later performed with local choirs and groups. In 2003, Terisa auditioned for the third season of the television show, American Idol. Though she did not make it to the top 12, her audition caught the attention of many and she gained a loyal following. This led to her receiving numerous opportunities to perform and collaborate with other artists. Throughout her career, Terisa has released several albums and singles including "Revival of Soul", "Soulzophrenic", and "Save Me". In addition to her music career, she has also acted in a number of films and television shows including "Empire" and "Chicago Fire". Terisa’s music style has been described as a blend of soul, R&B and gospel. Her powerful vocals and emotive performances have gained her recognition from industry legends such as Stevie Wonder, Chaka Khan and Quincy Jones. Beyond her musical and acting career, Terisa is also involved in philanthropic work. She supports various charitable organizations like St. Jude’s Children’s Hospital and The United Negro College Fund. Terisa continues to perform and tour, sharing her talent and passion for music with audiences around the world. Her dedication, talent and drive have cemented her as one of the most influential singers of her generation.

The 1969 Texas A&I Javelinas football team represented Texas A&I University—now known as Texas A&M University–Kingsville—in the 1969 NCAA College Division football season. Coached by Gil Steinke, the Javelinas finished the season with an overall record of 10–0 and were crowned NAIA National Champions. The team was led by quarterback Rocky Perez, who threw for 1,784 yards and 12 touchdowns, and running back Alvin Maxson, who rushed for 1,247 yards and 15 touchdowns. The defense was also dominant, allowing just 8.6 points per game while recording five shutouts. The Javelinas started the season with a 26–6 victory over St. Mary's University and continued their winning ways throughout the regular season, recording dominant victories over opponents such as Sul Ross State, Howard Payne, and Southwest Texas State. In the NAIA National Championship game, the Javelinas faced off against the Parsons College Vikings. It was a hard-fought game, with both teams trading blows throughout. In the end, Texas A&I emerged victorious with a 21–18 victory, securing their first national championship title. The 1969 Texas A&I Javelinas are remembered as one of the greatest football teams in the history of the university. Several members of the team went on to have successful careers in professional football, including Rocky Perez, who played for the Houston Oilers and the New York Giants, and Alvin Maxson, who played for the Kansas City Chiefs. Today, the legacy of the 1969 Texas A&I Javelinas lives on in the university's football program, and the team remains a symbol of excellence and achievement for generations of Javelinas football players and fans.

Schizopygopsis is a genus of freshwater fish belonging to the family Cyprinidae. Native to the high-altitude lakes and rivers of the Tibetan Plateau and surrounding areas, Schizopygopsis is notable for its adaptations to cold, oxygen-poor environments. Schizopygopsis species typically have elongated bodies, flattened heads, and small eyes, all adaptations for life in fast-moving, high-altitude waters. They are often found in rocky streambeds and can tolerate water temperatures as low as 0 degrees Celsius. Schizopygopsis species are also known for their ability to survive in water with low oxygen levels, which is rare among fish. Several species within the Schizopygopsis genus have been described by researchers. These include Schizopygopsis malacanthus, Schizopygopsis pylzovi, and Schizopygopsis younghusbandi. Most species are commercially valuable food fish, and several are considered endangered due to overfishing and habitat destruction. Schizopygopsis is closely related to another genus of cold-water adapted cyprinids, Platypharodon. Together, these two genera are known as the "Tibetan loaches," a reference to their elongated, snakelike bodies and bottom-dwelling habits. While Schizopygopsis is relatively obscure to the wider world, it holds an important place in the ecology and culture of the Tibetan Plateau. Its cold- and oxygen-tolerant adaptations make it an important indicator species for the health of high-altitude freshwater ecosystems. Additionally, Schizopygopsis and Platypharodon have been an important part of the local diet and economy for hundreds of years, and continue to be so today.

Joanne Leonard is an American artist and photographer, born in 1940 in New York City. Leonard is known for her poignant and intimate photographs that explore the complexities of human relationships and the passage of time. Leonard holds a Bachelor of Fine Arts from the Pratt Institute in New York and a Master of Arts from the University of Wisconsin. She began her career as an educator, teaching at various institutions including the University of Michigan and the College for Creative Studies in Detroit. Leonard has been an influential teacher, mentor, and inspiration to countless students of photography. Leonard's work has been exhibited nationally and internationally and can be found in many public and private collections. Her photographs have been featured in numerous books and publications, including Aperture magazine, The New York Times, and The Nation. Leonard's photographs often capture ordinary moments and people, but imbue them with a sense of beauty, nostalgia, and depth. Many of her works explore themes of childhood, family, and memory. One of her most famous series, "The Circus in Winter," chronicles the lives of circus performers and the rigors and joys of their work. In 2016, the Yale University Art Gallery hosted a retrospective of Leonard's work that featured more than 100 photographs spanning her career. The exhibition catalog, Joanne Leonard: The Consistently Inconsistent Photographs, includes essays by leading scholars of photography and art history. Throughout her career, Joanne Leonard has been an innovator and influencer in the field of photography, pushing the boundaries of what the medium can convey and expressing the complexities of the human experience.

Symphony No. 4 is a classical music composition by the Polish composer Karol Szymanowski. The piece is also known as Symphonie Concertante and was first performed in 1933 in Warsaw. Szymanowski's Symphony No. 4 is unique in that it combines elements of a symphony with a concerto. It is a work for solo piano, orchestra, and chorus, and can be described as a hybrid of the two genres. Despite its unusual composition, the Symphony No. 4 is widely regarded as one of Szymanowski's most important works. The piece is composed of three movements. The first is marked Allegro molto and is characterized by its syncopated rhythms, jazz-inspired harmonies, and rich orchestration. The second, marked Andante molto sostenuto, is a lyrical and expressive movement that features a haunting melody played by the solo piano. The final movement, marked Allegro vivace, is a lively and rhythmic finale that showcases the technical prowess of both the soloist and the orchestra. The piece also incorporates a chorus in the final movement, singing a text derived from Persian poetry. Szymanowski's Symphony No. 4 is a prime example of the composer's unique musical voice. With its combination of contrasting elements and its incorporation of Eastern-themed melodies and rhythms, the piece reflects Szymanowski's interest in Eastern culture and his desire to create a new, distinctly Polish style of classical music. The Symphony No. 4 is regularly performed and recorded by orchestras around the world. It is considered a masterpiece of Polish classical music and a testament to Szymanowski's skill as a composer.

The History of Karachi dates back to prehistoric times. The city is believed to have been the home of the ancient Indus Valley Civilisation, which flourished around 3500 BCE. Karachi has been controlled by various empires throughout history, including the Greeks, the Arabs, and the Mughals. The city of Karachi was originally a small fishing village called Kolachi. The village was located on the Arabian Sea and was an important trading post for spices and other goods. In the eighteenth century, the British East India Company took control of the area and established a port at the village. The port became an important center for trade, and the city began to grow rapidly. During the British colonial period, Karachi remained a major port city, and its population continued to grow. After Pakistan gained independence from British rule, Karachi became the country's capital. The city continued to grow rapidly, and by the 1970s, it had become one of the largest cities in the world. Throughout its history, Karachi has faced numerous challenges, including ethnic and political violence. In the 1980s and 1990s, the city was rocked by sectarian violence, which led to thousands of deaths. Despite these challenges, Karachi has continued to grow, and today it is a major economic hub for Pakistan. The city is also home to numerous historical and cultural landmarks, including the Masjid-e-Tooba, the National Museum of Pakistan, and the Karachi Port Trust Building. Overall, the history of Karachi is a rich and complex tapestry that reflects the city's diverse heritage and ongoing struggles. Today, Karachi remains an important center of commerce, culture, and innovation in South Asia.

Sonnia Agu was an American entrepreneur and beauty influencer known for co-founding the makeup brand, Ofra Cosmetics. Born in 1967 in Miami, Agu started her career as a cosmetologist in the early 1990s. She had a keen interest in the beauty industry and began experimenting with makeup and skincare products to understand the needs of her clients. In 1994, Agu founded Ofra Gaito Laboratories with her husband, a company that manufactured and distributed skincare and makeup products to salons and spas. The company quickly gained popularity and expanded its reach to retail stores. In 2007, they launched Ofra Cosmetics, a makeup line that gained a cult following among beauty enthusiasts for its high-quality formulas and trendy shades. Agu played a vital role in the development of Ofra Cosmetics and oversaw product development, marketing, and branding. She was also an active social media influencer, and her personal Instagram account had a significant impact on the brand's popularity. In 2018, Ofra Cosmetics was acquired by Guthy-Renker, a leading direct-to-consumer beauty company. Agu continued to be actively involved with the brand as its creative director. In addition to her work in the beauty industry, Agu was a philanthropist and was actively involved in supporting several charitable organizations. She was a strong advocate for causes related to women's empowerment and worked towards creating a more inclusive beauty industry. In 2020, Agu passed away at the age of 53 due to complications from Acute Myeloid Leukemia. Her legacy continues to inspire the beauty industry, and her contributions towards creating a diverse and inclusive space have left a lasting impact.

Riku Immonen is a Finnish former professional footballer who played as a midfielder. He was born on February 16, 1984, in Jyväskylä, Finland. Immonen began his football career in the youth team of his hometown club, JJK Jyväskylä, before moving to the formative stage of his career by joining FC Honka in 2000. Immonen made his professional debut for FC Honka in 2002 in the Finnish second-tier league, Kakkonen, where he proved his worth with his solid performances in midfield. In 2004, he helped the club achieve promotion to the Finnish top-flight, Veikkausliiga, where he played for three seasons before moving to another Veikkausliiga club, Tampere United. During his time at Tampere United, Immonen played an instrumental role in helping the club win the Veikkausliiga title in 2007 and the Finnish League Cup in 2008. He remained with the club until 2009 when he signed with another Finnish club, KuPS Kuopio. In 2010, Immonen noticed a change of scenery and signed with South Korean club FC Seoul, where he played for one season before moving to JEF United Chiba in Japan's J2 League. He later returned to Finland to play for IFK Mariehamn in 2012 and retired from professional football in 2015. Immonen earned his first international cap for Finland in 2005 and went on to make a total of 11 appearances for the national team. After retiring from football, Immonen has been involved in coaching and is currently working with the youth teams at JJK Jyväskylä, the club where he started his football career.

The Parliamentary Special Committee on Kashmir was established by the Government of India in August 2019. The committee was formed in response to the decision to revoke Article 370 of the Indian Constitution, which granted a special status to the state of Jammu and Kashmir. The purpose of the committee is to gather information and make recommendations on matters related to Jammu and Kashmir. The committee consists of members of both the Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha, with a total of 21 members. The committee has the authority to call for witnesses and evidence to assist with their inquiries, and can make recommendations to the Government of India on issues such as economic development, security, and human rights. The establishment of the committee has been seen as a positive step towards addressing the longstanding issues in Jammu and Kashmir. However, some critics have raised concerns about the committee's ability to provide unbiased recommendations, given the political polarisation in the region. The committee has already conducted several visits to Jammu and Kashmir to gather information and meet with stakeholders, including representatives from political parties, civil society groups, and security forces. The committee's findings and recommendations will be presented to the Government of India for consideration. The establishment of the Parliamentary Special Committee on Kashmir highlights the Government of India's commitment to promoting development, peace, and stability in Jammu and Kashmir. It also provides an opportunity for stakeholders to engage with the democratic process and have their voices heard.

Janssen is a Dutch surname, derived from the given name Jan, which is the Dutch form of John. It is a relatively common name in the Netherlands and among Dutch immigrants and their descendants in other countries. The name appears in various forms, including Jansen, Janssens, Janse, Jans, Janson, and others. Etymology The name Janssen is derived from the given name Jan, which is the Dutch form of John, a biblical name originating from the Hebrew name Yochanan (meaning "God is gracious"). The name Jan was a popular given name in the Netherlands during the Middle Ages and the Renaissance. It was often used in combination with other names, such as Jan Pieterszoon ("John, son of Peter") or Jan Willemszoon ("John, son of William"). Distribution Janssen is a common name in the Netherlands, where it ranks as the 7th most common surname. It is especially common in the southern provinces of Limburg and Noord-Brabant. According to the Dutch Central Bureau of Statistics, there were 200,152 people with the surname Janssen in the Netherlands in 2007. Outside of the Netherlands, Janssen is also found among Dutch immigrants and their descendants in other countries, such as the United States, Canada, Australia, and South Africa.
