She was steadfast in her determination to ensure that women were included in the political process and played an active role in shaping the future of the country. Muthoni wa Kirima died in 2021 at the age of 90. Her legacy lives on as a symbol of courage, bravery, and determination in the country’s struggle for independence from colonial rule. Her contributions to Kenyan political history will continue to be celebrated and remembered for generations to come.

10551 Göteborg is a minor planet in our Solar System, located in the Asteroid Belt. It was discovered on September 2, 1977 by Swedish astronomer Claes-Ingvar Lagerkvist at the Kvistaberg Observatory, located near Uppsala in Sweden. The planet is named after the city of Gothenburg in Sweden, which is known for its rich history and cultural significance. 10551 Göteborg orbits the Sun once every 4.32 years and is approximately 6.4 kilometers in diameter. It is classified as an S-type asteroid, which means it has a stony composition with little or no metal. The discovery of 10551 Göteborg was part of a larger effort to search for Near Earth Objects (NEOs) that could pose a threat to our planet. The Kvistaberg Observatory played a significant role in this effort and has discovered many asteroids and comets since its establishment in 1931. Despite its relatively small size, 10551 Göteborg is of great scientific interest as it offers insights into the formation and evolution of our Solar System. Scientists study minor planets like this to better understand the conditions that existed in the early Solar System, and how the planets and other celestial bodies formed. 10551 Göteborg is not visible to the naked eye and can only be observed through telescopes. It poses no threat to Earth, as its orbit does not cross our planet's orbit. In summary, 10551 Göteborg is a minor planet in the Asteroid Belt with a stony composition and a diameter of approximately 6.4 kilometers. It was discovered in 1977 by astronomer Claes-Ingvar Lagerkvist and is named after the city of Gothenburg in Sweden. While not visible to the naked eye, it offers valuable insights into the formation and evolution of our Solar System.

FSV Wacker 90 Nordhausen is a German football club based in Nordhausen, Thuringia. The club was founded in 1890 as FC Wacker Nordhausen and has undergone several name changes throughout its history. FSV Wacker 90 Nordhausen became the club's official name in 1990 after German reunification. The club has a long history in German football, having played primarily in the lower leagues. In the 2019/2020 season, FSV Wacker 90 Nordhausen played in the Regionalliga Nordost, which is the fourth tier of German football. FSV Wacker 90 Nordhausen's home games are played at the Stadion an der Wiedigsburghalle, which has a capacity of 7,000 spectators. The club's traditional colours are black and white. FSV Wacker Nordhausen has a strong rivalry with FSV Zwickau, which dates back to the GDR-era when the two clubs played in the same league. The derby between the two teams is often referred to as the "Osterland Derby". The club has a youth academy that provides training for young players. Some of the notable players who have played for FSV Wacker 90 Nordhausen include Falko Götz, who became the youngest player to play for the East German national team at the age of 17, and Andreas Thom, who played for the club during his youth career before going on to play for clubs like Bayer Leverkusen and Hertha BSC. In recent years, FSV Wacker 90 Nordhausen has achieved success in the Regional Cup, winning it in 2018 and 2019. The club has also made several appearances in the DFB-Pokal, which is the top domestic cup competition in Germany.

Jackson State Tigers basketball is the men's basketball program of Jackson State University in Jackson, Mississippi. The program was inaugurated in 1928 and is a member of the Southwestern Athletic Conference (SWAC). The Tigers play their games at the Lee E. Williams Athletics and Assembly Center, which has a seating capacity of 8,000. Throughout the history of the program, Jackson State has had several notable achievements. The team has made multiple appearances in the NCAA Tournament, including in 1999 under the direction of Head Coach Andy Stoglin. The team has won the SWAC Tournament Championship in seven different years (1957, 1962, 1963, 1993, 1999, 2000, and 2007) and has a total of 10 regular-season conference championships. Among the most notable athletes who have played for Jackson State Tigers basketball are Walter Payton, Lindsey Hunter, Philander Rodman, and Trey Johnson. Since the arrival of head coach Wayne Brent in 2013, the team's performance has improved significantly. Brent, who previously worked as an assistant coach for Mississippi State University and Ole Miss Rebels, led the team to its first NCAA Tournament appearance in over a decade in 2020. The Tigers also won their first SWAC championship since 2007 that same season. The Jackson State Tigers basketball program is known for its high tempo and defensively focused style of play. Brent has emphasized the importance of defense since his arrival, and under his leadership, the team has been one of the top defensive units in the SWAC. Overall, the Jackson State Tigers basketball program has a rich tradition and a dedicated fan base. With the team's recent success, there is optimism that the Tigers will continue to perform well in the future.

Platon Obukhov was a renowned Soviet astronomer and astrophysicist. He was born on September 8, 1903, in the Russian Empire and died on August 9, 1984, in Moscow, Soviet Union. Obukhov graduated from Moscow State University in 1926, where he studied mathematics and took up astronomy under the guidance of professor Yevgeny Yakhontov. After graduation, he worked at the Pulkovo Observatory in Leningrad (now Saint Petersburg) until 1931, when he returned to Moscow to work at the Soviet Academy of Sciences. Between 1936 and 1947, Obukhov worked as a senior research fellow at the Pulkovo Observatory, where he made several important contributions to the field of astrophysics. In particular, he studied the internal structure and evolution of stars, including the hydrogen burning reaction that powers stars like our sun. He also made important contributions to the theory of supernovae and the study of variable stars. Obukhov was also a prolific author, publishing more than 150 papers on astronomy and astrophysics over the course of his career. He was awarded the prestigious Stalin Prize in 1948 for his work on the structure of stars, and was later elected a corresponding member of the Soviet Academy of Sciences in 1953. Throughout his life, Obukhov remained active in the astronomical community, serving as the President of the Soviet Astronomical Society from 1955 to 1960. He continued to research and publish on topics in astrophysics until his death in 1984. Today, Obukhov is remembered as one of the most important Soviet astronomers of the 20th century, and his contributions to the field continue to be studied and celebrated by astronomers around the world.

Wang Xiaoyun is a Chinese mathematician and computer scientist known for her contributions to the field of cryptography. She was born on May 28, 1966, in Shandong, China. Wang Xiaoyun completed her undergraduate studies at Shandong University before attending Tsinghua University for her graduate studies. She earned a master's degree in computer science in 1990 and a Ph.D. in cryptography in 1996 from Tsinghua University. After completing her Ph.D., Wang Xiaoyun joined the faculty at Shandong University, where she became a professor of mathematics and computer science. In 2003, she moved to the School of Electronics Engineering and Computer Science at Peking University, where she currently holds the position of professor. Wang Xiaoyun is best known for her work in the area of hash function cryptography. She is one of the co-developers of the widely used cryptographic hash function called SM3, which is used in China for secure communication and data storage. She has also made important contributions to the understanding of collision resistance in hash functions. Wang Xiaoyun has received many awards and honors in recognition of her contributions to cryptography. In 2010, she became a fellow of the International Association for Cryptologic Research, and in 2018, she was awarded the prestigious China National Award for Natural Science. Outside of her research, Wang Xiaoyun is a passionate advocate for women in science. She has served as the president of the Chinese Women in Mathematics Association and is an active member of the Committee for Women in Mathematics of the International Mathematical Union. Wang Xiaoyun's contributions to the field of cryptography have made her one of the most recognized and respected researchers in the area. Her dedication to promoting the participation of women in math and science has also earned her a place as a role model for young researchers around the world.

Vincenzo Cabianca (1827-1902) was an Italian painter known for his work in the Romantic style during the 19th century. He was born in Verona, Italy and began his artistic career as a student of Antonio Bresciani, a local painter. Cabianca was a prominent figure in the Italian art scene during his time, not only for his paintings but also for his involvement in the cultural and political movements of the period. He was a member of the group called "Scapigliatura" ("The Disheveled"), a movement of artists and writers who sought to break free from the constraints of academic art and literature. Cabianca's style was characterized by a preference for dark colors and bold brushstrokes, which were used to create a sense of dramatic mood in his paintings. He also excelled in portrait work, capturing the emotions and personalities of his subjects with great skill. One of Cabianca's most famous works is "The Last Days of Napoleon", which depicts the emperor's exile on the island of Saint Helena. The painting was displayed at the International Exposition of Paris in 1878 and received critical acclaim, cementing Cabianca's reputation as a master of historical painting. In addition to his artistic pursuits, Cabianca was also involved in the political and social issues of his time. He was a supporter of the Risorgimento movement, which aimed to unify Italy under a single government, and was involved in the movement for women's rights. Cabianca's legacy in the Italian art scene can still be felt today, as his works continue to be displayed in museums and collections throughout Italy and the world. His contribution to the Romantic style has also solidified his importance in the history of Italian art.

Calgary Tigers were a professional ice hockey team that played in the Western Canada Hockey League (WCHL) from 1920 to 1926. The team was known for its immensely talented players and successful campaigns, which saw them win multiple championships and establish a strong fan base. Founded in 1920, the Tigers played their home games at Victoria Arena in Calgary, Alberta. The team was owned by George B. Noonan, who also served as the team's first coach. Noonan was succeeded as coach by Alf Smith, a former NHL player, in 1923. Smith led the team to further success, winning three consecutive championships from 1924 to 1926. The Tigers boasted a roster of notable players, including Eddie Shore, Duke Keats, and Red Dutton. Shore, in particular, was a standout player and would go on to have a Hall of Fame career in the NHL. Meanwhile, Keats was known for his offensive prowess, becoming the first player in professional hockey to tally over 100 points in a season. Despite their successes, the Tigers faced financial difficulties, which led to the team's demise in 1926. The team was sold and became the American Hockey Association's Chicago Cardinals. The Tigers' legacy, however, lives on, with their successes and impact on hockey in Western Canada being remembered and celebrated. In recent years, there have been attempts to revive the Tigers, with various groups using the name and logo to create new teams. These teams, however, have not been affiliated with the original Tigers organization.

The 1986 Philippine presidential election, also known as the Snap Election, was held on February 7, 1986. It was the first presidential election held under the new Constitution of the Philippines, which was ratified in 1983. The election was called by President Ferdinand Marcos, who sought to legitimize his more than twenty years of martial rule by winning a fresh mandate. The main opposition contender was Corazon Aquino, the widow of slain opposition leader Benigno Aquino Jr. Aquino ran under the banner of the United Nationalist Democratic Organization (UNIDO), which was composed of various opposition parties and groups, including the Lakas ng Bayan (People Power) movement. She was joined by former senator Salvador Laurel as her running mate. Marcos, on the other hand, ran under the Kilusang Bagong Lipunan (New Society Movement), the political arm of his regime. He was supported by various politicians, businessmen, and military officials. The election was marred by widespread allegations of fraud, violence, and intimidation. The Commission on Elections (Comelec) declared Marcos the winner with 10,807,197 votes, while Aquino garnered 9,291,700 votes. However, the opposition, led by the Catholic Church and various civil society groups, challenged the results and launched a campaign of mass protest and civil disobedience. The culmination of this movement was the People Power Revolution, a peaceful uprising that saw millions of Filipinos take to the streets in Manila and other cities. The military, which was previously loyal to Marcos, eventually shifted its allegiance to the opposition, and Marcos fled the country on February 25, 1986. Aquino was sworn in as the new President of the Philippines, marking a new era in Philippine politics. The 1986 Philippine presidential election remains a pivotal moment in Philippine history and democracy, as it led to the restoration of democratic institutions and the rule of law. It also inspired other movements for non-violent resistance and civil disobedience around the world.

Littlehampton Town F.C. Littlehampton Town F.C. is an English football club based in the town of Littlehampton, West Sussex. The club was founded in 2000 and currently plays in the Southern Combination Football League Premier Division, which is the ninth level of the English football pyramid. History Littlehampton Town F.C. was formed in 2000 by a group of local football enthusiasts. The club's first competitive season was in the West Sussex Football League Division Five. The club quickly progressed through the divisions and in the 2006-2007 season, they won the West Sussex Football League Division Two title. In the 2007-2008 season, Littlehampton Town F.C. joined the Sussex County League Division Three and finished in a respectable fifth position. The club maintained their position in the division for several seasons before being promoted to the Division Two in the 2011-2012 season. The club finished as runners-up in the 2012-2013 season and earned promotion to the Sussex County League Division One. Littlehampton Town F.C. spent two seasons in the Sussex County League Division One before being relegated back to the Division Two in the 2014-2015 season. The club remained in the division for four seasons before moving to the Southern Combination Football League Division One in the 2018-2019 season. The club gained promotion to the Southern Combination Football League Premier Division in the 2019-2020 season. Stadium Littlehampton Town F.C. play their home matches at The Sportsfield which is located on St. Floras Road, Littlehampton. The stadium has a capacity of 1,000 spectators. Honours - West Sussex Football League Division Two Winners: 2006-2007 - Sussex County League Division Two Runners-up: 2012-2013 References - Littlehampton Town F.C. on Soccerway - Littlehampton Town F.C. on the Sussex County Football League website - Littlehampton Town F.C. on the Southern Combination Football League website.

When God Writes Your Love Story is a book written by Eric and Leslie Ludy, a couple who lives life with the main aim of serving God. The book was published in 1999 by Multnomah Publishers. The book talks about how to build a God-centered and fulfilling relationship. It mainly focuses on how to let God lead one to find true love and build a romantic relationship that not only honors God but is also happy and fulfilling. In the book, Eric and Leslie talk about how they met and how their relationship grew as they put God first. Throughout the book, they stress the importance of listening to God's guidance when it comes to finding love and building a lasting relationship. The book has 11 chapters, each with a different topic that can help couples build a God-centered relationship. The topics range from knowing and fulfilling your personal relationship with God, to pursuing purity and chastity, to trusting God with every aspect of the relationship, and seeking godly counsel. When God Writes Your Love Story is a book that has helped many couples build lasting and fulfilling relationships that honor God. The book encourages individuals to focus on God and his will when it comes to relationships, and it gives hope to those who may have lost faith in love. The Ludy's lived the principles they wrote about – their relationship is proof that when you allow God to write your love story, it can be an incredibly joyous and fulfilling experience. The book has been translated into several languages and has touched the lives of countless people around the world.

Temple of Bellona, Rome The Temple of Bellona is an ancient Roman temple dedicated to the goddess of war, Bellona. It is located in the southern part of Rome, near the Circus Maximus. The temple was built during the Republican period in Rome, around the 3rd century BCE. The temple was designed in the Etruscan style and built of brick and travertine, with a podium of tufa. It was a simple rectangular structure with a front porch supported by two columns and two pilasters. The temple was surrounded by a portico with columns and had a cella, or inner sanctuary, where the statue of Bellona was located. The cult of Bellona was associated with the Roman army, and the temple served as a place of worship and sacrifice for soldiers. It was also used for public events and ceremonies related to the military, such as triumphs and prayer for victory in battle. The temple was destroyed in the 6th century CE during the Gothic Wars and was later converted into a church in the 9th century. The church was dedicated to St. Andrew, but the original structure of the temple was still visible in its architecture. During the Renaissance, the church was given a Baroque façade, which covered most of the remaining ancient structure. However, the interior still contains some remnants of the original structure, including the cella and some of the columns. Today, the Temple of Bellona is a popular tourist attraction for those interested in ancient Roman architecture and history. It is also still used as a place of worship, hosting occasional religious services and ceremonies.

Colonial Forge High School is a public high school located in Stafford County, Virginia, United States. The school is part of the Stafford County Public Schools, which serves the surrounding area. The school was founded in 2007 and has since become one of the most highly regarded schools in the county. The school's campus is situated on 65 acres of land, which includes a football stadium, a baseball field, tennis courts, and a softball field. The school also has a state-of-the-art library, science and technology labs, as well as a fine arts center. The school offers a rigorous academic program that prepares students for college and career success. Students have the opportunity to earn college credits through dual enrollment programs and Advanced Placement courses. The school also offers a wide variety of extracurricular activities, including athletics, clubs, and organizations. Colonial Forge has a strong athletic program with teams in football, basketball, baseball, volleyball, cross country, track and field, and more. The school's football team has won several conference championships and has produced several standout players who have gone on to play at the college level. The school has also been recognized for its academic achievements. In 2019, the school was named a Blue Ribbon School by the U.S. Department of Education, which is awarded to schools for their overall academic excellence. Colonial Forge High School is committed to providing students with a well-rounded education that prepares them for success in whatever path they choose. The school's dedicated teachers and staff work tirelessly to create a positive and nurturing learning environment, and the school's students are consistently recognized for their academic and athletic achievements.

Matthew 8 is the eighth chapter of the Gospel of Matthew in the New Testament of the Christian Bible. This chapter opens with the story of Jesus healing a leper, and it goes on to detail several other significant events in Jesus' ministry. In the first story of the chapter, Jesus heals a person with leprosy. This event underscores Jesus' compassion and power, as lepers were considered outcasts in ancient society. Jesus then proceeds to heal a paralyzed man, using the power of his words alone. The chapter also contains several more miracles performed by Jesus, including the healing of a Roman centurion's servant, calming a storm on the sea of Galilee, and casting demons out of two men in a cemetery. One of the most significant moments in this chapter is Jesus' encounter with two men who were possessed by demons. The demons begged Jesus to send them into a herd of pigs, which he did, and the pigs then ran down a steep bank and drowned. This event is often cited as an example of Jesus' power over evil spirits. Another important theme in Matthew 8 is Jesus' role as a healer. He is shown to have the power to cure physical ailments and to bring peace to troubled souls. This underscores his divine nature and reinforces his message of hope and salvation for all who believe in him. Overall, Matthew 8 is an important chapter in the Gospel of Matthew, illustrating Jesus' compassion, power, and role as a healer and Savior to all who seek him.

Walcheren Barracks is a military installation located in the city of Arnhem, in the eastern part of the Netherlands. The barracks are named after the island of Walcheren, which saw significant military action during World War II. The barracks are home to the 11th Infantry Battalion of the Royal Netherlands Army. The construction of the barracks was completed in the 1970s and they replaced earlier barracks built in the city. The barracks are primarily used for training soldiers and for administrative purposes. The facilities at the barracks include an obstacle course, firing ranges, and classrooms for training. The barracks played an important role in the Battle of Arnhem, which took place in September 1944. During the battle, British and Polish paratroopers attempted to seize key bridges and capture the city. However, the German defenders were able to hold them off and the battle resulted in a decisive German victory. The Walcheren Barracks are a reminder of the sacrifices made by the Allied forces during the battle and of the bravery of those who fought there. Today, the Walcheren Barracks are an important training center for the Dutch military. They are used to train soldiers in a wide range of skills, from marksmanship to leadership. The barracks are also used as a base for the 11th Infantry Battalion, which is one of the most highly trained and respected units in the Netherlands Armed Forces. In addition to its military importance, the Walcheren Barracks are also a popular tourist attraction. Visitors can take guided tours of the facilities, watch military demonstrations, and learn about the history of the area. The barracks are an important part of the cultural heritage of Arnhem and a testament to the courage and bravery of those who have fought and died in defense of the Netherlands.

USS Hollister (DD-788) was one of the 173 Gearing-class destroyers built for the United States Navy during and after World War II. Commissioned in 1945, the ship was named after Rear Admiral Harold W. Hollister, who served during the Spanish-American War and served as the commander of the US Naval Base at Subic Bay during World War II. Hollister served in the Pacific during the Korean War and the Vietnam War, earning ten battle stars for her service. The ship was decommissioned in 1975 and subsequently sold for scrap. Hollister was laid down on 22 November 1943 by Bethlehem Steel Corporation at San Francisco, California. She was launched on 21 May 1944, sponsored by Mrs. H.W. Hollister, widow of Rear Admiral Hollister, and commissioned on 9 December 1944. After her commissioning, Hollister joined the Pacific Fleet and supported the war effort in the Pacific during World War II. Hollister saw combat in the Korean War and earned two battle stars. During the Vietnam War, Hollister provided gunfire support and served as an escort for aircraft carriers. She received eight battle stars for her service in Vietnam. In addition to her combat service, Hollister served as a training platform for naval midshipmen and provided humanitarian aid after natural disasters. Despite her long service, Hollister was decommissioned on 4 December 1975 and subsequently sold for scrap. USS Hollister earned a distinguished place in the annals of United States Naval history as a highly decorated combat vessel with a record of service during three wars. Today, she is remembered as an important contributor to American naval forces during the mid-20th century.

An Inconvenient Tax is a 2011 documentary film produced and directed by Christopher Marshall and starring Americans for Tax Reform president Grover Norquist, Boston University economics professor Laurence Kotlikoff, and former Reagan administration economist Peter Ferrara. The film argues that the United States tax system is unfair, complicated, and inefficient, and it advocates for a complete overhaul of the tax code. The documentary uses interviews with economists, business owners, and taxpayers to illustrate the problems with the current system, including high tax rates, excessive regulations, and loopholes that benefit the wealthy. It suggests that a flat tax or a consumption tax would be more fair and simpler, eliminating many of the problems with the current system. An Inconvenient Tax took its title from the 2006 documentary An Inconvenient Truth, which dealt with the issue of global warming and climate change. The producers of the film chose this title to emphasize the complexity and confusion of the tax system, which can create a burden for taxpayers. The film received mixed reviews, with some critics praising its advocacy for tax reform and others criticizing its oversimplification of the issues and its one-sided focus on conservative perspectives. Despite these criticisms, An Inconvenient Tax has become a popular entry point for many viewers to learn about the problems with the U.S. tax system and the potential for reform. In conclusion, An Inconvenient Tax is an American documentary that acts as a call for tax reform in the United States. Through a combination of expert commentary, interviews, and data, the documentary highlights the complexity and inefficiency of the American tax system and suggests a flat tax or consumption tax as a solution. The film has been both praised and criticized, but has become an important reference point for those seeking a better understanding of the current state of the American tax system.

Mike Perry (born September 1, 1981) is an American designer, artist, animator, author and creative director based in Brooklyn, New York. He gained recognition in the early 2000s for his bold, energetic designs and illustrations that frequently use bright colors, playful typography and a childlike sense of wonder. Perry studied graphic design at Minneapolis College of Art and Design before embarking on his career. He worked at Pentagram Design and later started his studio, Mike Perry Studio, in 2006. His studio has produced work for clients such as Coca-Cola, Nike, ESPN, and The New York Times. In addition to his commercial work, Perry has also gained a reputation for his fine art. He has exhibited his work at galleries and museums around the world, including the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis and the Museum of the City of New York. His work is often marked by a sense of playfulness and surrealism, with recurring motifs such as smiling faces, abstract shapes and vibrant colors. In 2012, Perry released his first book, "Hand Job: A Catalog of Type," which is a collection of over 350 hand-drawn fonts. His second book, "Over and Over," was released in 2017 and includes 300 of his art pieces featuring bright colors, bold shapes and quirky characters. In recent years, Perry has also focused on his passion for animation and directed his own animated series “Kid’s Storytime” for Amazon Prime, as well as the music video for “Feel Alright” by Poolside. He also launched “Mike Perry’s Pretty Thoughts,” a line of playful and upbeat stationery and homegoods. Overall, Perry has become a prominent figure in the design world through his creative works and unique aesthetic. His art continues to inspire and engage audiences with its playful and optimistic tone.

Richard Duncan is a retired American athlete who was known for his prowess on the track and field. He was born on October 1, 1945, in Meridian, Mississippi, and began his athletic career in the 1960s. Duncan was a standout performer in college at Southern University in Baton Rouge, Louisiana. He was a member of the university's track and field team and was an All-American in both the 100-yard dash and the 220-yard dash in 1966 and 1967. His success in college earned him a place on the United States Olympic team in 1968. At the 1968 Summer Olympics in Mexico City, Duncan competed in the 200-meter dash and won a bronze medal, finishing behind Tommie Smith and Peter Norman of Australia. Duncan also competed in the 4x100-meter relay, in which the U.S. team was favored to win, but was unfortunately disqualified in the final due to a baton exchange violation. Duncan continued to compete at a high level after the Olympics, winning several national titles in both the 200-meter and 400-meter dashes. He also set several world records during his career. After retiring from competition, Duncan was involved in coaching and worked as a television sports commentator. In 2002, he was inducted into the USA Track & Field Hall of Fame. Duncan's accomplishments on the track and field continue to inspire young athletes today. His legacy is one of perseverance, hard work, and dedication to the sport of track and field.

Formosa Peak is a mountainous peak located in the eastern region of Taiwan. It is also called Qilai South Peak and is part of Taiwan's Central Mountain Range. The peak is known for its steep slopes and is one of the highest points in Taiwan, standing at an elevation of 3,339meters (10,953ft) above sea level. Formosa Peak is one of the most challenging peaks to climb due to its technical difficulty and unpredictable weather conditions. The peak was previously known as "Chilai South Peak" before being renamed Formosa Peak in 1949. The name ‘Formosa’ came from the Portuguese phrase “Ilha Formosa,” which means ‘beautiful island.’ This was the term used by the Portuguese explorers when they first arrived on the island of Taiwan. In 1949, when the Kuomintang government moved to Taiwan from mainland China, they renamed a number of places in Taiwan, including Chilai South Peak, which was changed to Formosa Peak. Formosa Peak is a popular destination for hikers. The peak can be accessed from different hiking trails, but the two most popular trails are the Wu-Ling Route and the Baiyue Trail. The Wu-Ling Route is the most challenging route, and typically takes 2-3 days to complete. The Baiyue Trail, on the other hand, is the most popular and offers beautiful views of the surrounding landscape. It takes around 10-12 hours to complete the Baiyue Trail. The views from Formosa Peak are breathtaking. The peak offers a 360-degree view of the surrounding landscape and the eastern coast of Taiwan. The surrounding area is also home to some of Taipei's most beautiful waterfalls, streams and bamboo forests. In addition to hiking, Formosa Peak is also a popular destination for rock climbing and camping. The mountain is known for its steep, rocky terrain, which provides a challenging, but rewarding experience for rock climbers. Campers can also enjoy the beauty of the mountain range and surrounding wilderness. However, due to the unpredictable weather conditions, it is essential to plan ahead and prepare for any eventualities. Overall, Formosa Peak is a truly magnificent peak and a must-visit destination for outdoor enthusiasts. Whether you prefer hiking, rock climbing or camping, Formosa Peak offers a unique and unforgettable adventure.

West Liberty Foods is a food processing company headquartered in West Liberty, Iowa, United States. Founded in 1996, the company specializes in the production of turkey products and fully prepared protein entrees and snacks. West Liberty Foods operates four processing plants located in Iowa, Utah, and Illinois. The company's products are sold throughout the United States as well as internationally, with a focus on private label and co-pack business. The company has a strong commitment to quality, food safety, and sustainability. It is a certified member of the American Humane Certified program, which ensures that all animals are treated humanely. West Liberty Foods is also committed to reducing its environmental footprint, with initiatives including the use of renewable energy and water conservation measures. West Liberty Foods has received numerous awards and recognitions, including the National Turkey Federation’s Chairman’s Award for Excellence, the Safe Quality Food Institute’s Excellent rating, and the Iowa Turkey Federation’s Processor of the Year. In addition to its production facilities, West Liberty Foods has its own culinary team and research and development department, which allows the company to develop and produce unique and innovative products for its customers. West Liberty Foods has a strong corporate culture centered around teamwork, innovation, and continuous improvement. The company encourages its employees to take ownership of their roles and to contribute ideas that can help drive growth and improvement. Overall, West Liberty Foods is a leader in the food processing industry, with a focus on quality, sustainability, and innovation. Its commitment to excellence has helped it build strong relationships with customers and employees alike.

Obsession is a song by Swedish music group Army of Lovers. It was released in 1991 as the lead single from their second studio album, Massive Luxury Overdose. The song was written by Alexander Bard and Anders Wollbeck, with Bard also serving as producer. Obsession is notable for its infectious beat and catchy chorus, and is considered to be one of Army of Lovers' most recognizable songs. The track features vocals by Jean-Pierre Barda and Michaela de la Cour, with backing vocals provided by Dominika Peczynski. The music video for Obsession was directed by Fredrik Boklund, and features the members of Army of Lovers performing the song in a futuristic, neon-lit setting. The video was highly popular upon its release and helped to establish the band as one of the most visually striking acts of the early 90s. "Obsession" was an instant commercial success, reaching number one on the Swedish singles chart and making the top ten in several other European countries. The song's success helped to establish Army of Lovers as one of the most popular and influential European pop acts of the 90s. Although Army of Lovers never achieved the same level of mainstream success in the United States as they did in Europe, "Obsession" was a minor hit on US dance charts and helped to establish the band as a cult favorite among American dance music fans. In conclusion, "Obsession" remains one of Army of Lovers' most enduring and beloved tracks, and its catchy chorus and infectious beat continue to captivate listeners to this day.

The Institute for East European Studies (IEES) is a research institute located in Berlin, Germany. It is affiliated with the Free University of Berlin and was founded in 2005. The primary aim of IEES is to research and analyze the political, social, and economic developments in Eastern Europe. IEES's core activities include research, teaching, and academic events. Researchers at IEES investigate a broad range of topics such as political transitions, democratization, regional security, and European integration. The institute is committed to producing high-quality research and publications that are accessible to scholars, policy-makers, and the general public. IEES's teaching activities include supervising doctoral students and offering courses on Eastern Europe. These courses are designed to provide students with an in-depth understanding of the region's history, politics, and culture. IEES also organizes academic events such as workshops, conferences, and lectures. These events bring together scholars, policymakers, and journalists to discuss key issues relating to Eastern Europe. IEES has a strong network of partnerships with academic institutions, think tanks, and policy organizations in both Europe and the United States. These partnerships include the Centre for East European and International Studies (ZOiS), the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars, and the European Council on Foreign Relations. IEES is also active in promoting academic exchange and cooperation between Germany and Eastern Europe. The institute offers scholarships and research grants to scholars from the region and hosts visiting scholars from Eastern Europe. In summary, IEES is a leading research institute on Eastern Europe that provides high-quality research, teaching, and academic events. The institute is committed to promoting academic exchange and cooperation with scholars and institutions from the region.

Charles Ray Hatcher was an American serial killer who is known to have killed 16 people and suspected of killing at least three more. He was born on July 16, 1929, in Mound City, Missouri, and died on December 7, 1984, at the age of 55, while serving a life sentence at the Missouri State Penitentiary. Hatcher's criminal history began in his teenage years, where he was arrested for stealing cars and committing burglaries. In the 1960s, he was diagnosed with paranoid schizophrenia and was institutionalized for a brief period. However, he was released and resumed his criminal activities. Throughout the 1970s, Hatcher committed a series of murders, with his victims including women, children, and elderly individuals. He was known for leaving behind a distinct pattern of violence that would go on to link him to other murders. Hatcher was finally arrested in 1982, after DNA evidence linked him to the murder of Nancy Kitzmiller, a four-year-old girl whose body was found in Missouri. Following his arrest, he confessed to several of his other murders and was convicted for 16 counts of homicide. Hatcher's case is notable for being one of the first to use DNA evidence in a criminal trial. He was sentenced to life in prison and died of heart failure in 1984. Though he is known to have killed 16 people, it is suspected that his actual death toll is much higher. Today, Charles Ray Hatcher is remembered as one of the most prolific serial killers in American history. His story has been the subject of various books, documentaries, and television shows.

Joseph H. Allen was a notable American inventor and businessman who made significant contributions to the field of telecommunications. He was born on May 1, 1880, in Brookline, Massachusetts and died on November 11, 1962, in New York City. Allen graduated from Harvard University in 1904 and started his career in the telecommunications industry. He served as the president of the Western Electric Company from 1922 to 1940. During his tenure, he oversaw the development of the first practical audio amplifier and the construction of the world's largest telephone factory. In 1940, Allen was appointed as the president of AT&T, which was then the largest telecommunications company in the world. His leadership was instrumental in expanding the company's services and keeping it profitable during World War II. Under his guidance, AT&T made important technological advances, including the development of the microwave radio relay system, which enabled long-distance calls without the need for physical cables. Allen was also a visionary entrepreneur who understood the importance of investing in research and development. He encouraged his engineers to explore new ideas and technologies, which resulted in numerous patents and innovations that made AT&T a leader in the telecommunications industry. In addition to his professional achievements, Allen was also active in philanthropy and civic affairs. He worked closely with the Boy Scouts of America and was a member of several prestigious organizations, including the Council on Foreign Relations and the Harvard Board of Overseers. Joseph H. Allen's contributions to the telecommunications industry continue to impact our lives today. His innovative ideas and visionary leadership helped shape the modern world of communications.

Antares is a red supergiant star located in the constellation Scorpius. It is the brightest star in the constellation and the 15th brightest star in the night sky. Its name comes from the Greek word meaning "rival of Mars" because of its intense reddish hue resembling that of the planet. Antares is also known as Alpha Scorpii, as it is the brightest star in the pattern of Scorpius. Antares has a radius estimated to be around 883 times that of the Sun, making it one of the largest known stars. It is also one of the most massive, with a total mass estimated to be around 12 times that of the Sun. Antares is estimated to be around 550 light-years away from Earth. Despite its size and brightness, Antares is a relatively young star, with an estimated age of between 10 and 20 million years. Due to its massive size, Antares is expected to end its life in a supernova explosion, although this is not expected to happen for at least a few hundred thousand years. Antares has a companion star, which is much smaller and cooler than the main star. This companion star is difficult to observe directly due to its proximity to the much brighter main star. Antares has been observed by astronomers for thousands of years, and has been used as a navigational aid by sailors and travelers throughout history. In recent years, Antares has been studied extensively by astronomers using telescopes and other advanced instruments in order to learn more about its structure, evolution, and potential for future supernova explosions. Overall, Antares is an important and fascinating star that has captured the imagination of astronomers and stargazers alike for generations.

Wesley Jobello is a professional football player from France. Born on March 12, 1993, in Marseille, Jobello began his footballing career at a young age, joining the youth academy of AC Ajaccio. He progressed through the ranks of the club's youth system and went on to make his debut for the senior team in 2012. Jobello is primarily a winger, known for his pace, dribbling ability, and his capacity to score goals. After spending his youth career at AC Ajaccio, he moved to Marseille Consolat in 2014. His spell at the club was short-lived as he joined Grenoble Foot 38 in 2015. He became one of the standout performers for the club, helping them secure promotion to the National League in his first season. In 2017, Jobello signed with Stade Lavallois in the Championnat National. He helped the club reach the playoffs in his first season, scoring some important goals along the way. After a year with Laval, Jobello signed with GFC Ajaccio, where he continued to impress with his performances. In 2019, Jobello joined English side Coventry City on a three-year deal. After a tough start to life in England, Jobello began to show his skills as the season progressed. He scored his first goal for Coventry in December 2019, against Ipswich Town. Despite suffering a cruciate ligament injury in February, Jobello remained optimistic about his future at Coventry and is determined to make an impact in the team when he returns. In conclusion, Wesley Jobello is a talented footballer who has played for several clubs in France and currently plays for Coventry in England. He is known for his pace, dribbling ability, and his capacity to score goals from midfield. Despite a setback with an injury, Jobello remains focused on his career and is determined to make a significant impact at Coventry in the future.

Tsoro is a traditional board game that is popular in many parts of Africa. It is played on a board that consists of several small pits or hollows that are arranged in a symmetrical pattern. Each pit can hold a certain number of objects, such as seeds, stones or shells, which are used as playing pieces. The objective of the game is to capture as many of the opponent's pieces as possible. The rules of Tsoro vary from region to region and from culture to culture. However, the basic gameplay involves players taking turns to sow (distribute) their pieces into the adjacent pits. This is done by picking up all the pieces from one pit and distributing them, one by one, into the neighbouring pits in a clockwise direction. If the last piece lands in an empty pit, the turn ends. If the last piece lands in a pit that already has pieces, the player picks up all the pieces in that pit and continues sowing them into the adjacent pits. There are different ways to capture pieces in Tsoro. In some variations, a player can capture an opponent's pieces by sowing into a pit that is opposite a pit with only one of the opponent's pieces. This is called "cross-capture". Another way to capture pieces is by forming a line of three pieces in a row. When this happens, the player can remove one of the opponent's pieces that is not part of the line. The game ends when one player has no more pieces left on the board or cannot make any more moves. Tsoro is not only a form of entertainment but also a means to bond with family and friends and teach important life skills such as strategizing and decision-making. It is also a way to pass down cultural values and traditions from one generation to another. In recent years, Tsoro has gained popularity outside of Africa, with many people around the world discovering and enjoying the game.

Henri Nathansen (17 May 1868 – 6 December 1944) was a Danish writer and playwright. Born in Copenhagen, Nathansen was a son of Polish-Jewish immigrants. He worked as a librarian and a journalist before becoming a full-time writer. Nathansen was a prominent figure in Danish cultural and intellectual life in the early 20th century. He was one of the founders of the influential cultural magazine "Klingen" and was a member of the Royal Danish Academy of Fine Arts. Nathansen's literary output included plays, novels, and essays, and he was known for his social criticism and engagement in humanist causes. Nathansen's best-known work, the play "Mandschauvinisten" (Male Chauvinists), was first performed in Copenhagen in 1909. The play was a satire on the bourgeois society of the time, focusing on the oppression of women. Nathansen's plays often dealt with feminist themes and were considered revolutionary for his time. In 1915, Nathansen published "En dansk krigsfange i Tyskland" (A Danish Prisoner of War in Germany), a memoir of his time in a German prison camp during World War I. The book was well-received and helped to establish Nathansen as a major literary voice. Nathansen was active in the resistance movement during the German occupation of Denmark in World War II. He was arrested by the Gestapo in 1944 and died in captivity shortly thereafter. Nathansen's legacy as a writer and cultural figure in Denmark is significant. His plays are still performed today and his social commentary on gender and class struggles remain relevant. Nathansen's life and work are a testament to his commitment to humanist values and his dedication to the cultural and intellectual life of Denmark.

Presidential State Car (Brazil) The Presidential State Car of Brazil, also known as the "Rolls-Royce Silver Wraith II", is a vehicle used by the President of Brazil for official and ceremonial purposes. The car is known for its distinct black color and presidential seal on the front doors. History The Presidential State Car was first introduced in the early 1960s when Juscelino Kubitschek was president of Brazil. The car was acquired from Rolls-Royce, a British luxury car manufacturer famous for producing cars for heads of state around the world. The first car was a Rolls-Royce Silver Cloud I, which was used by the president until 1964. In 1968, following a military coup, the presidential car was replaced with a Ford Galaxie, a car that was produced locally in Brazil. However, in 1973, President Emílio Garrastazu Médici purchased the Rolls-Royce Silver Wraith II, which has been in use ever since. Specifications The Presidential State Car is a 1972 Rolls-Royce Silver Wraith II, equipped with a 6.75-litre V8 engine and a three-speed automatic transmission. The car measures 18 feet in length and weighs 2.25 tons. The car is capable of reaching a top speed of around 80 miles per hour. The car is fitted with bulletproof glass, armor plating, and run-flat tires, providing the highest level of protection for the president. The car also has an air conditioning system, intercom system, and a state-of-the-art security system. Use The Presidential State Car is used by the President of Brazil for official and ceremonial purposes. The car is used during state visits and other important events, such as the annual Independence Day parade in Brasília. The car is also used during the inauguration ceremony of each new president. In addition to the Presidential State Car, the president of Brazil also has access to a fleet of other vehicles, including helicopters and planes, for official travel. Conclusion The Presidential State Car of Brazil is an important symbol of the country's government and the president's authority. The use of a Rolls-Royce reflects the importance of the president's role in Brazilian society, and the car's unique features provide the highest level of security and protection for the president. The car remains an iconic symbol of the Brazilian presidency and is a point of pride for the country.

Frank Budd was an American athlete and a Track and Field sprinter, who was born on July 20th, 1939, in Long Branch, New Jersey. Budd was best known for his outstanding performance in the 100 meters during the early 1960s. Budd competed for Villanova University where he was a standout football player and an accomplished hurdler, before turning his attention to sprinting. In 1960, he finished as the national champion in 100 meters, running a time of 10.2 seconds. His performance earned him a place on the United States Olympic team. At the Summer Olympics held in Rome, Budd was chosen to represent the United States in the 100 meters race. He won his heat with a time of 10.5 seconds, and later qualified for the final with a time of 10.3 seconds in the semifinals. In the final, Budd finished fourth with a time of 10.4 seconds in a race that was won by the world record holder, Armin Hary of Germany. Budd continued to run world-class times after the Olympics, setting a world record in the 100-yard dash with a time of 9.2 seconds. He also won the AAU National Championships in the 100 meters in 1961 and 1962. Budd retired from competing in 1963 and went on to become an entrepreneur, opening a sporting goods store in New Jersey. He also served as a motivational speaker and a coach. Throughout his career, Budd stood out for his explosive speed, excellent form, and competitiveness. His achievements have inspired several generations of athletes and he is considered one of the all-time greats in American track and field history.

Marian Robertson Wilson (born May 2, 1969) is an American artist hailing from La Grange, Georgia. Inspired by nature and the simplicity of traditional crafts, Wilson uses a mixture of mediums such as watercolor, acrylic, and textile to create her works. She is known for her unique style that blends traditional and modern techniques to create intricate, colorful pieces that capture the essence of the natural world. Early Life and Education: Wilson grew up in La Grange, Georgia, where she developed her passion for art and nature at an early age. She attended the University of Georgia, where she received a degree in Art Education in 1991. Career: After graduation, Wilson taught high school art for several years before becoming a full-time artist in 2006. She has since exhibited her work in galleries across the United States and has been featured in numerous publications, including Southern Living Magazine, Needlepoint Now Magazine, and Artisan Spirit Magazine. Wilson's work is characterized by her love of nature and her unique interpretation of traditional crafts. She often incorporates materials such as embroidery floss, fabric, and beads into her pieces, creating stunning and intricate designs. Her work ranges from small, delicate watercolors to large, sprawling textile installations. Achievements: In 2016, Wilson was awarded the Georgia Council for the Arts Folklife Apprenticeship grant to teach traditional embroidery techniques to a local apprentice. Her work has also been featured in several public art installations, including a large-scale mural in downtown La Grange. Personal Life: Wilson currently resides in La Grange, Georgia, with her husband and two children. When she is not creating art, she enjoys hiking, gardening, and spending time with her family. Legacy: Marian Robertson Wilson is recognized for her unique style and approach to art. Her work has resonated with people around the world and continues to inspire future generations of artists.

The flag of Dorset consists of a stylized golden dragon on a green and white background. The design was created in 2008 by a group of flag enthusiasts in Dorset who wanted to give their county its own distinct flag. The dragon on the flag is based on a carving that was found on a Viking longboat that was discovered in Dorset. The green and white colors were chosen to represent the county's natural beauty, from the rolling hills of the countryside to the white cliffs of the coast. The flag was officially registered with the Flag Institute in 2008, and has since become a popular symbol of pride for the people of Dorset. It is flown at local events and festivals, and has even been raised at international sporting events to represent the county. In recent years, the flag has been used by various organizations as a way to promote Dorset and its culture. It has been featured on tourism brochures, merchandise, and even on the side of a local bus. Some have criticized the flag for being too simplistic or not representative enough of the county's history and traditions. However, supporters of the flag argue that it is a unique and modern design that reflects the diverse and dynamic nature of Dorset today. Regardless of any controversy, the flag of Dorset remains an important symbol of pride and identity for the people of this historic county.

Claudia Ruggerini is an Italian former athlete and Olympic gold medalist. Born on January 13th, 1965 in Forlì, Italy, she became a track and field star in the 1980s and 1990s competing in the 100 meters hurdles. Ruggerini’s professional career began in 1981 when she won a silver medal at the European Junior Championships in the 100-meter hurdles. She quickly staked her claim as one of the world’s top hurdlers. In 1986, she won the 60-meter hurdles at the World Indoor Championships held in Indianapolis. A year later, she won a bronze medal in the 100-meter hurdles at the World Championships held in Rome. Her greatest achievements came at the 1988 Summer Olympics in Seoul. Despite sustaining an injury in the semifinals, Ruggerini fought through the pain and won the gold medal in the 100-meter hurdles, becoming the first Italian woman to win a gold medal in athletics. She also won a silver medal in the 4 × 100 meters relay, alongside teammates Liliana Bortoluzzi, Giovanna Fortunato, and Marina Trivellini. In addition to her Olympic and World Championships success, Ruggerini also won several European medals, including three golds, two silvers, and one bronze medal. After her athletic career, Ruggerini became an athletics coach. She has served as a coach for the Italian national athletics team, as well as several Italian clubs. She has also served as a television commentator for major athletics events. Ruggerini was awarded the Cavaliere Ordine al Merito della Repubblica Italiana (Knight Order of Merit of the Italian Republic) in 1989. She was inducted into the Italian Athletics Federation Hall of Fame in 2015. In conclusion, Claudia Ruggerini was a trailblazing athlete and accomplished coach who left a significant impact on Italian athletics. Her Olympic gold medal in the 100-meter hurdles will forever be remembered as a key milestone in Italian sports history.

Emma Chambers (soubrette) was a British actress and comedienne, best known for her role as Alice Tinker in the popular BBC sitcom, The Vicar of Dibley. Born on March 11, 1964, in Doncaster, South Yorkshire, Chambers began her acting career in the 1980s and quickly made a name for herself as one of Britain's finest comic actors. Chambers' first major break came in 1994 when she was cast as Alice Tinker in The Vicar of Dibley. The show, which revolves around the life of a female vicar, played by comedian Dawn French, was an instant hit and ran for seven seasons until 2007. Chambers' portrayal of the hapless Alice, who was constantly getting herself into awkward situations, won her critical acclaim and endeared her to audiences around the world. Chambers also appeared in a number of other popular British TV shows during her career, including How Do You Want Me?, Take a Girl Like You, Skullduggery, and Martin Chuzzlewit. She also appeared in several films, including Notting Hill and the TV movie The Wind in the Willows. Sadly, on February 21, 2018, Chambers passed away at the age of 53. Her death was the result of a heart attack. The news of her passing was met with great sadness by fans and colleagues alike, who paid tribute to her as a gifted actress and a wonderful person. Despite her untimely passing, Chambers' legacy as a talented comic actor lives on. Her work in The Vicar of Dibley and other productions has made her a much-loved figure in British popular culture, and her memory continues to inspire and entertain audiences around the world.

Gaius Julius Eurycles was a prominent Roman citizen who lived during the reign of Emperor Nero. He was born into a wealthy family and inherited a significant fortune from his parents, which he used to finance his political ambitions and patronage of the arts. Eurycles was known for his eloquence and his ability to sway the opinions of others. He was a skilled orator and was frequently called upon to deliver speeches in the Senate and other public gatherings. His persuasive powers earned him the respect and admiration of his peers, and he quickly rose through the ranks of Roman society. In addition to his political career, Eurycles was also a patron of the arts. He supported many of the greatest poets, musicians, and artists of his time, including the philosopher Seneca and the poet Lucan. He was a great lover of music and is said to have written several popular songs himself. Eurycles was also known for his philanthropy. He was a generous donor to many charitable causes, including the funding of public works such as aqueducts, temples, and roads. He was regarded as a benefactor to the people of Rome and was often lauded for his generosity and kindness. Despite his success, Eurycles was not without his enemies. His opponents accused him of corruption and graft, and he was eventually forced to defend himself in court. Although he was found innocent of the charges against him, his reputation was tarnished, and he retired from public life. Today, Gaius Julius Eurycles is remembered as a great orator, patron of the arts, and philanthropist. His legacy continues to inspire future generations to strive for excellence and to give back to their communities.

Integral Linearity Integral linearity is a term used in electronics and signal processing to describe the linearity of an analog-to-digital converter (ADC). It refers to the relationship between the input voltage to the ADC and the digital output code produced by the converter. Specifically, integral linearity describes the error or deviation in the output code compared to the expected ideal output code for a given input voltage. In an ideal ADC, the output code would be perfectly linear with respect to the input voltage. However, due to imperfections in the converter's design, such as non-ideal components or manufacturing variations, there can be deviations from this ideal behavior. Integral linearity is one important specification used to quantify the performance of an ADC. Integral linearity is typically measured as the maximum deviation from the ideal output code, expressed as a percentage of the full-scale input voltage range. For example, a 12-bit ADC with a range of 0 to 5 volts might have an integral linearity specification of +/-0.5 LSB (least significant bit), which corresponds to a maximum deviation of 0.024% of the full-scale range. Improving integral linearity generally requires improving the accuracy of the analog portions of the ADC, such as the reference voltage and the input buffer. Other important specifications for an ADC include resolution, signal-to-noise ratio, and conversion speed. In summary, integral linearity is an important specification for analog-to-digital converters that describes the accuracy of the converter's output code with respect to the input voltage. Improving integral linearity requires improving the accuracy of the converter's analog components.

Francis D. Williams House was a historic home located in the Hyattsville community of Prince George's County, Maryland. This house was built in 1905 for Francis D. Williams, who was a prominent attorney and a notable figure in Maryland's legal community. The house was designed in the Colonial Revival style by architect Albert L. Skinner, who was well-known for his work in Maryland and the District of Columbia. The house featured a symmetrical facade with a central entrance flanked by two large Ionic columns, a hipped roof, and dormer windows. The house was inhabited by the Williams family until the mid-20th century when it was sold to a doctor. In the 1970s, the house fell into disrepair and was abandoned. It was later acquired by the City of Hyattsville in the 1990s and was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1994. Despite being protected by its historic designation, the Francis D. Williams House suffered severe damage due to a fire in 2019. The structure was deemed unsafe and was later demolished, much to the disappointment of the local community. Today, the site of the Francis D. Williams House remains vacant. The City of Hyattsville has expressed interest in potentially using the site for a public park or another community use. Despite the loss of this historic building, its memory lives on as a testament to the architectural and cultural heritage of Hyattsville and Prince George's County.

Bolesław II the Generous, also known as Bolesław II the Bold, was a prominent figure in the history of Poland. He was born in the year 1042 as the son of Casimir I the Restorer and his wife Maria Dobroniega of Kiev. He ruled as Duke of Poland from 1076 until his death in 1081. Bolesław II was known for his generous nature and was famous for his many acts of charity towards the poor. He also made many contributions to the development of the Polish state during his reign. He founded numerous towns, cities, and churches across the country and played a crucial role in the adoption of Christianity by the Polish people. One of Bolesław II's most significant achievements was his successful war campaigns against the Holy Roman Empire. The war between Poland and the Empire, known as the Saxon Wars, had been going on for 12 years before Bolesław II came to power. He managed to defeat the Empire in 1079, which resulted in the recognition of Poland's sovereignty by the Holy Roman Emperor, Henry IV. Bolesław II's reign was also marked by his efforts to strengthen the royal authority in Poland. He initiated a series of reforms aimed at improving the economic and social conditions in the country. For example, he introduced new laws that protected the rights of farmers and artisans and regulated trade and commerce. Despite his many successes, Bolesław II's reign was not without controversy. He was accused of betraying the Holy Roman Empire after the Saxon Wars by supporting the Pope during the Investiture Controversy. Moreover, he was criticized for his harsh treatment of his brother, Władysław Herman, who he had imprisoned after seizing the throne. Bolesław II the Generous died in 1081 and was buried in the Cathedral of Poznań. His reign had a significant impact on the history of Poland and is remembered to this day as a time of great progress and development.

Brymbo F.C. is a Welsh football club based in the village of Brymbo, Wrexham County Borough, North Wales. The club was founded in 1946 and played its games at the Cae Y Castell Ground, Brymbo. They currently play in the Welsh National League Premier Division. Brymbo F.C. has had a long and proud history in Welsh football, particularly in local leagues. The club has won numerous cups and league titles since its inception, establishing itself as a major force in the Welsh National League Premier Division. The club's peak came in the early 2000s, when they reached the Welsh Cup semi-finals twice in 2001 and 2003, losing out to Barry Town and The New Saints (TNS) respectively. Despite this, they were unable to gain promotion to the Welsh League Premier, and continue to compete in the Welsh National League. In recent years, Brymbo has seen a resurgence, with the club winning the Welsh National League Premier Division in the 2017/18 season. This success was followed by another cup win in the FAW Trophy, where they defeated fellow Welsh National League Premier Division club Llanrug United in the final. Notable former players include Jacob Barratt and Shaun Tuck, who both went on to play professional football with Wrexham A.F.C. and The New Saints FC respectively. Overall, Brymbo F.C. has established itself as a strong and respected club in Welsh football, and continues to grow and achieve success within its local leagues.

Petunia Pig is a fictional character in the Looney Tunes and Merrie Melodies series of cartoons. Created by animator Frank Tashlin, she is one of several female characters that were introduced as love interests for Porky Pig. Petunia Pig first appeared in the 1937 short film, "Porky's Romance". Petunia has a pink complexion and wears a red bow on her head. She is portrayed as a kind, gentle, and sophisticated character. In contrast to Porky, who is often depicted as bumbling and nervous, Petunia is confident and self-assured. She is also portrayed as intelligent and self-reliant. In many of the cartoons, Petunia and Porky's relationship is depicted as a courting one. Porky often goes to great lengths to impress Petunia or win her affections. However, Petunia is usually unimpressed by Porky's antics and is more interested in his sincerity and caring nature. Petunia has appeared in numerous Looney Tunes and Merrie Melodies shorts over the years, including "Piggy's Diner" (1939), "The Major Lied 'Til Dawn" (1941), and "Hush My Mouse" (1946). She has also appeared in comic books and various other forms of media. Despite being a relatively minor character in the Looney Tunes universe, Petunia Pig has become a beloved character to many fans. She is often cited as a positive role model for young girls, as she is depicted as intelligent, independent, and kind-hearted. Her relationship with Porky has also become a popular subject for fan fiction and fan art.

The Dayton Family is an American rap group from Flint, Michigan. The group is composed of Ira Dorsey, Raheen Peterson, and Matt Hinkle. The Dayton Family is known for their gritty, streetwise lyrics and their social commentary on the issues of poverty, drugs, and crime in urban America. The group formed in the early 1990s and released their debut album, What's On My Mind? in 1995. The album gained critical acclaim for its honest portrayal of street life and the struggles faced by those living in poverty-stricken neighborhoods. The Dayton Family's second album, F.B.I., released in 1996, continued this theme and explored the topic of police brutality and corruption. The Dayton Family released several more albums throughout the 1990s, including 1998's Attitude Adjuster and 1999's Welcome to the Dopehouse. The group's music often featured politically charged and controversial lyrics, which stirred controversy and attracted both criticism and praise from music critics and fans alike. Despite their confrontational style and controversial lyrics, The Dayton Family has maintained a dedicated fan base and continued to release music into the 2000s. Their most recent album, Charges of Indictment, Vol. 2, was released in 2015. The Dayton Family's influence on the rap scene in Michigan and beyond cannot be overstated. The group's unflinching portrayal of life in urban America has inspired countless other artists and provided a voice for those living in marginalized communities. The Dayton Family's music remains a testament to the struggles and experiences of those living in poverty and stands as a reminder of the ongoing fight for justice and equality in America.

The Meade Conflict was a major confrontation that occurred during the American Civil War. It was fought between the Union Army of the Potomac, led by Major General George G. Meade, and the Confederate Army of Northern Virginia, commanded by General Robert E. Lee. The conflict took place from July 1 to July 3, 1863, in and around the town of Gettysburg, Pennsylvania. It was the bloodiest battle ever fought on American soil, with an estimated 50,000 casualties. The Meade Conflict was a critical turning point in the war. Prior to the battle, Lee's army had won a string of victories and was on the offensive. If they had won at Gettysburg, they could have marched on Washington, DC, and possibly forced an end to the war in favor of the Confederacy. However, Meade's forces held the high ground and were able to repel wave after wave of Confederate attacks. On the second day of the battle, Lee attempted a flanking maneuver that failed, costing him valuable troops and momentum. On the third day, Lee ordered a charge across open ground towards the Union center, now known as Pickett's Charge. The charge was met with devastating fire from Union artillery and muskets, resulting in thousands of Confederate casualties. Lee was forced to withdraw from the battlefield, effectively ending his invasion of the North. The victory at Gettysburg rallied Union morale and marked the turning point of the war. It is considered one of the most significant battles in American history. In conclusion, the Meade Conflict, also known as the Battle of Gettysburg, was a pivotal moment in American history. It demonstrated the strength and resilience of the Union Army and marked the beginning of the end for the Confederacy. The battle is remembered today for its valor, sacrifice, and meaning in shaping the United States as we know it today.

Hibbard & Darrin was a prestigious luxury car design firm founded in the early 20th century by Howard C. Hibbard and Thomas L. Hibbard. The firm specialized in creating custom-bodied automobiles for wealthy clients, most notably during the 1930s and 1940s. Their designs were known for being opulent, elegant, and sophisticated, and the cars they produced were some of the most beautiful and sought-after vehicles of their time. Howard C. Hibbard and Thomas L. Hibbard both had extensive experience in the automobile industry before forming their partnership. Howard had worked as a designer for various car manufacturers and was known for his sleek, streamlined creations. Thomas, on the other hand, had expertise in business and sales and was highly skilled in communicating with clients. The duo began working together in the early 1920s, creating designs for various car manufacturers. They soon gained a reputation for their innovative and stylish designs, and in 1929, they established their own design firm, known as Hibbard & Darrin. One of the firm's most famous designs was the "Hibbard & Darrin Convertible Victoria," which was produced in the 1930s and featured a sleek, curved body and luxurious interior. The car was popular with movie stars and other high-profile clients. In the early 1940s, the firm was acquired by the Briggs Manufacturing Company, and the Hibbard & Darrin name was eventually phased out. However, the designs and legacy of the firm continued to influence the automobile industry for decades to come. Today, Hibbard & Darrin cars are highly sought after by collectors and enthusiasts alike, and their designs remain an enduring symbol of luxury and elegance.

Herman te Riele (born August 18, 1947) is a Dutch mathematician known for his contributions to number theory. He is recognized for his algorithmic research in prime numbers and is regarded as one of the foremost contemporary experts in the field. Te Riele obtained a PhD in mathematics from the University of Amsterdam in 1973, under Professor Hendrik W. Lenstra. He joined the staff of the same university, where he worked until his retirement in 2012. In 1976, te Riele collaborated with fellow mathematician Adriaan van der Poorten to study the diophantine equation ax^2 + by^2 = c. They developed an algorithm to determine the solvability of this equation for given values of a, b, and c. This algorithm, now known as the te Riele-van der Poorten algorithm, remains a significant contribution to the field of number theory. Another significant contribution by te Riele is his work in the field of prime numbers. He is known for his discovery of the largest known Mersenne prime in 1989, which has over 2 million digits. In 2013, he further extended this discovery by finding the largest known prime number at the time, which had over 17 million digits. His work on prime numbers has led to improvements in encryption algorithms that rely on prime numbers for their security. Te Riele was awarded the Dutch Mathematical Society's Spinoza Prize in 1996, the highest honor in Dutch science, and the London Mathematical Society's Senior Berwick Prize in 2012. He continues to be an active member of the mathematics community, serving as an editorial board member of several prestigious mathematical journals. In summary, Herman te Riele is a prominent mathematician who has made significant contributions to number theory, particularly in the fields of diophantine equations and prime numbers.

Jonathan Tel is an award-winning British author and poet. He was born in London in 1963 and raised in Nigeria and England. His works include short stories, novels, and poetry collections. He has received numerous awards and recognitions for his literature. Tel’s first publication was the poetry collection Aardvarks & Diamonds, which was published in 1991. Two years later, he released his first novel, Freud's Alphabet, which won the Commonwealth Writers’ Prize for Best First Book in 1993. The novel explores the relationship between language and memory through the stories of seven characters. His second novel, The Beijing of Possibilities, was published in 2009. It was shortlisted for the Commonwealth Writers’ Prize and longlisted for the Frank O’Connor International Short Story Award. The novel is set in contemporary Beijing and follows the lives of various characters as they navigate their personal and professional lives in the city. Tel has also published several short story collections, including The Half-Life of Songs (2006) and Scratching the Surface (2015). His stories have been anthologized in many publications, including Best British Short Stories and The O. Henry Prize Stories. In addition to his literature, Tel has also worked as a translator. He has translated works from German, French, and Hebrew into English. He has been awarded the Schlegel-Tieck Prize for German Translation and the PEN Award for Poetry in Translation. Tel currently lives in Hong Kong, where he teaches creative writing at the University of Hong Kong. He continues to write and publish works of fiction and poetry.

Screen direction, also referred to as scene direction, is an aspect of filmmaking that determines how characters and objects move within the frame of a shot. It refers to the direction in which the action is taking place, as observed by the camera and the audience. In filmmaking, the screen is typically divided into two halves - the left and the right. The movement of characters and objects between the two halves is known as crossing the line, or the 180-degree rule. The 180-degree rule is a fundamental principle of screen direction that filmmakers abide by to prevent visual confusion for the audience, ensuring continuity and coherence throughout a film. The 180-degree rule states that the camera should always remain on one side of an axis, an imaginary line running through the main subjects of a shot, to preserve the spatial orientation of the characters and their relationships within the frame. Violating this rule can cause confusion, disorientation, and distract from the story being told. Screen direction also helps to convey the emotional intensity of a scene. For example, a character moving towards the camera can convey aggression or confrontation, while a character moving away from the camera can indicate fear, submission, or escape. In addition to its practical applications, screen direction also plays a crucial role in the overall artistry of a film. A director can use screen direction to convey the tone and mood of a scene, and to establish character relationships. In conclusion, while screen direction might seem like a technical aspect of filmmaking, it is essential to the seamless telling of a story through film. It contributes to the overall coherence and clarity of a film, and helps to create a world and characters that are both believable and engaging to audiences.
